questions.question: What advantages come with opening a German current account?
Which documents are needed to open a current account in Germany?
How can I apply for a German current account online?

context:
Bank account (current account)
Why do I need a current account?
A current account is an account for people who want to make payments via the bank .
Your money is always available in your current account.
With a current account you can:
Make transfers
Receive cashless payments (payments from public offices / authorities / social benefits are often made cashless, i.e. transferred to a personal current account)
Set up standing orders
Participate in direct debits
Cashing cheques, making cashless payments with the EC / Maestro card
Withdraw cash at bank counters or ATMs
Print out your account statements
Opening an account
Different banks offer current accounts on different terms.
Find out exactly how much a current account costs each month and what services the bank offers in return.
How do I open an account?
Decide which bank you would like to have an account with.
Make an appointment to open an account.
Bring the following documents with you to the appointment:
Identification document (proof of arrival, residence permit, authorisation to stay, tolerated stay permit, identity card)
If no current address is noted on the identification document: please bring a registration certificate or a comparable document with you
Important: If you do not speak German or English, please bring an interpreter with you.
Further multilingual information on this topic can be found here.
Important information:
After opening the account, you will receive an EC card with a four-digit PIN code.
Sign the back of the EC card.
Memorise the PIN code.
You will need the PIN code for cashless payments and for withdrawing money from ATMs.
Be sure to keep your card and PIN code separate!
If you want to withdraw cash: It is best to use the ATMs of the bank where you have your account.
Then the withdrawal costs nothing.
If the PIN code is entered incorrectly three times at the ATM, the debit card will be withdrawn and blocked.
In this case, you must ask your bank.
If your EC card is lost or stolen, have it blocked immediately.
State your sort code and account number.
Then ask your bank for a new EC card.
Monday to Friday from 0 - 24 hrs

questions.question: Which groups are exempt from Germany's minimum wage law?
How can I check if I am eligible for a minimum wage exemption?
What are the current minimum wage rates in Germany?

context:
Minimum wage
Germany has a statutory minimum wage.
The amount is increased regularly.
The minimum wage may not be reduced by working longer hours than contractually agreed without corresponding wage compensation.
The minimum wage does not apply to:
Young people under the age of 18 without completed vocational training
Apprentices
Long-term unemployed persons during the first six months of their employment after the end of unemployment
Trainees in certain types of internship (school or study-related internship or
Internships for professional orientation up to three months)
Voluntary activities
Self-employed
You can find more information here.

questions.question: How can I get financial support for studying in Germany?
What types of scholarships are available for international students?
How can I apply for study financing as a refugee in Germany?

context:
How can I finance my studies?
Federal Training Assistance Act (BAföG)
BAföG means Bundesausbildungsförderungsgesetz (Federal Training Assistance Act) and is a financial support.
You can apply for this if you are studying in Germany.
BAföG is money from the state.
You get it into your account every month.
Half of the amount is free money.
As soon as you have a job and earn money after your studies, you have to pay back the other half of the money.
You can then pay back the money in small instalments.
BAföG can be applied for by people who live and study in Germany.
Even if you do not have a German passport, you can apply for BAföG.
You can get more information here.
You can also call the BAföG hotline free of charge:
Monday - Friday from 8 a.m. - 8 p.m
The application for BAföG must be submitted in writing to the relevant student union.
Make sure that your application is submitted early.
This is because it takes several months to process the applications.
You can find the application forms here.
Grants
There are many grants you can apply for.
And not just in the first semester, but throughout your studies.
Here you can get an overview.
These schemes are sometimes very different from each other.
In some cases, value is placed on social commitment or attention is paid to political orientation, course of study, grades or personal circumstances.
Working student
Many courses of study offer the opportunity to work as a student trainee in a company.
There you can gain your first experiences in the field you have studied and earn money on the side.
The companies mostly offer contracts on a 10-20 hours/week basis.
If you perform well, there is a chance of being taken on after graduation.
Get information from companies in your area.
The concept of the working student is widespread.
Student assistant
As a student assistant, you can usually work at a university for a maximum of 20 hours a week.
In doing so, you will complete tasks that will help, for example, a lecturer, a chair or an organisation of the university.
The prerequisite is enrolment at a university as a student.
These positions are advertised at the universities.
Side job and holiday job
Many students have a side job to finance their studies.
There are different types of side jobs.
If you receive a state subsidy, find out how much you can earn in addition.
State support is, for example, BAföG or a scholarship.
Many students work in a so-called mini-job.
You earn a maximum of 450 € per month.
But you don't pay taxes and social security contributions.
Some also work in holiday jobs during the semester breaks.
If you earn more than 520 € per month in a holiday job, you should note the following: if you do not work for longer than 3 months or a total of 70 working days, the job is also social security-free.
Education loan
The education loan is a low-interest loan from the state-owned Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau (KfW).
It is specifically aimed at students who are in the final phase of their studies .
Unlike normal bank loans, you do not need collateral such as your own income.
The income of parents or a spouse is also irrelevant.
Here you will find further information on the subject of educational loans.

questions.question: What social benefits can I access as a refugee in Germany?
How is taxation handled for refugees in Germany?
Where can I get help with tax-related issues in Germany?

context:
Social justice
The state must respect and protect human dignity.
Therefore, it should ensure social justice in the best possible way.
It takes legal, financial and material actions to do so.
All people in Germany who earn money pay part of their wages to the state.
The higher your income, the more you have to pay.
The more you earn, the more taxes you pay.
The state is supposed to spend this money on the welfare of the people living in Germany.
This means, for example:
Every person registered as living in Germany has the right to basic medical care.
This includes medical treatment in the case of illness or accident.
All people who have a job that is subject to social insurance pay contributions to health insurance, long-term care insurance and pension insurance.
Every adult must make an effort to pay for their own living expenses.
If a person is not able to do this, they can request support from the state.
The state ensures that taxes are used to reduce social inequality and help people in crisis (refugees, for example).
The state provides financial support to parents, for example through child benefits.
This is not allowedin Germany, for example:
Tax fraud, for example paying fewer taxes than required.
Receiving state benefits without being entitled to them.

questions.question: How can I use my foreign driving license in Germany?
What is the process to get a German driving license?
How much does it cost to get a German driving license?

context:
Cars
Driving licence
If you drive a car in Germany, you must have a valid driving licence and always carry it with you.
In Germany, you can drive a car from the age of 18 and with a valid driving licence.
There is also the option of taking the driving licence at the age of 17.
You want to get your driving licence?
If you want to get your driving licence, choose a driving school.
The driving school will explain which documents you need and how to proceed.
Getting a driving licence costs money.
Please enquire in advance about the amount of these costs.
In order to get a German driving licence, you must pass the theoretical and the practical exam.
The theoretical examination can be taken in many languages other than German.
Talk to your driving instructor about this.
You must also attend a first aid course.
There you will learn how to provide help in an emergency situation, for example in case of accidents, burns and poisoning.
Here you can find more information and contact details on how to apply for a driving licence at the district office.
You already have a foreign driving licence?
You have a foreign driving licence and live in Germany?
In this case, your foreign driving licence is still valid for 6 months after you moved to Germany.
After these 6 months, you must transferyour driving licence to a German driving licence.
You will also have to take a theoretical and practical exam.
Persons from EU/EEA states with a valid driving licence do not need to transfer their foreign driving licence.
Here you can get further information as well as applications for the transfer of your driving licence.
Note: To ensure that road traffic is safe for you and others, there are many rules.
You must observe these when driving a car.
These rules are laid down in the Straßenverkehrs-Ordnung (StVO).
If you break these rules, you will be fined.
Penalties can be: Fines, a driving ban or points on your licence.
Here you will find further information in several languages.
Register a car
You would like to buy a motor vehicle (for example car, truck, motorbike, scooter) and drive it?
Then you must register (register) this motor vehicle.
To do this, you must go to the “Zulassungsstelle” (Registration Office).
Please make an appointment online inadvance.
Waiblingen, Schorndorf and Backnang
Here you will find all important information on admission and the contact details of the respective locations.

questions.question: How can I rent an apartment in Germany?
What documents are needed for apartment rental?
Where can I find affordable apartments for rent?

context:
I have found an apartment
Rental contract
The amount of rent is agreed in the rental contract.
When tenants sign a rental contract, they agree to pay that amount of rent.
The rent is made up of cold rent (basic amount), ancillary costs (refuse collection, operating costs) and heating costs.
The date that rent is due is agreed upon in the lease contract.
If the rent is increasingly not paid on time, this can lead to termination of the lease contract.
You need to read the lease carefully.
If you do not understand everything, ask somebody who can help you.
The rental contract is very important.
Once it is signed, it cannot be cancelled so quickly!
The contract must include the following points:
Name and address of the landlord
Address of the rental object
Living space in m²
Number of rooms
Amount of the net base rent
Agreed amount of operational costs
Amount of heating costs
Total rent
Amount of damage deposit
If you agree with what the lease says, then sign it.
For more information in several languages, click here.
Deposit
The deposit is a security for the landlord/landlady.
The amount for the damage deposit is a maximum of 3 base rents.
When you move out of the property, you will get the money back, provided that you have not caused any damage.
Possible cost absorption
If you receive money from the Jobcentre or the Landratsamt , you must observe the following:
Important: You may not signthe tenancy agreement yet, but must first have it approved.
First of all, you need to get an estimate from your future landlord.
This should include:
The amount of the rent
The amount of any additional costs (heating, water, electricity)
The amount of the deposit
Possible graduated rent (automatic increase of the rent)
You must go to the Job Centre / Landratsamt with the cost estimate.
They check the cost estimate.
If everything is in order, they'll approve it.
If you have a residence requirement, you must submit an application to the Aliens' Registration Office (Ausländerbehörde).
Initial equipment
If you receive benefits from the Job Centre, you have the possibility to apply for initial equipment for furniture and furnishings.
You will be paid a lump sum.
It is important that the application is made before the furniture is purchased
Caution: It may take a while before the money is paid out!
In addition, the Job Centre has the right to inspect the flat in order to check the amount of the initial equipment.
Info for refugees: When moving out of accommodation, you are not allowed to take the furniture of the accommodation with you.
That is why you need new furniture.
You can apply to the Job Centre for initial outfitting.
Housing benefit
If you and the people living with you in the household earn little money, you are entitled to housing benefit under certain conditions.
If you get money from the state for yourself and your family, you will not usually need to apply for housing benefit.
Information on housing benefit in the Rems-Murr district

questions.question: What are the limits of free speech in Germany?
Can I protest in Germany and how?
What should I do if I feel my freedom of expression is violated?

context:
Freedom of expression
All people are allowed to form their own opinions, to express and disseminate them freely.
People are also allowed to express these opinions publicly.
All media are also free, all people can inform themselves there.
Anyone who freely expresses his or her opinion must pay attention to the protection of personal honour or the personal dignity of other people.
That means, for example:
The government may be criticised.
Religion may be criticised.
Artistic works may provoke.
No one may dictate to writers, musicians or visual artists how they should work.
Government and religions may also be the subject of satire and critical art.
Anyone who feels insulted or his or her personal honour or dignity violated can turn to the police or to a court.
This is not allowed in Germany, for example:
The use of anti-constitutional symbols and calls to overthrow democracy.
Insulting expressions of opinion that disparage other people.
Defamation or slander against other people.
Inciting hatred and violence.

questions.question: Which jobs can I do with Duldung?
How can I get permission to work with Duldung?
What is the difference between Duldung and Aufenthaltserlaubnis?

context:
May I work with a tolerated status?
Permission to work with a Duldung depends on this,
whether you live in an initial reception centre or have already been placed outside the initial reception centre
how many months you have already been in Germany.
They still live in the initial reception centre
If you are in possession of a “Duldung” (toleration) for 0-6 months, then you are not allowed to work.
If you have held the Duldung according to §60a for at least 6 months , then gainful employment is only permitted with the approval of the Aliens' Registration Office.
You will find this notice on your identity document as a secondary provision.
An employment permit can be issued to you.
You must complete and sign the job description and the declaration of employment and hand it in to the Aliens' Registration Office.
The approval of the “Bundesagentur für Arbeit” (Federal Employment Agency) is requested by the “Ausländerbehörde” (Immigration Office).
In doing so, it checks the working conditions (for example, minimum wage, scope of work).
They no longer live in the initial reception centre
If you are in Germany for 0-3 months, you are not allowed to work.
If you have already been in Germany for 4 months, you can apply for an employment permit at the Aliens' Registration Office.
Your identity document says "Gainful employment only permitted with the permission of the foreigners authority."
This means that you must complete and sign the job description and declaration of employment and hand it in to the Aliens' Registration Office.
The approval of the “Bundesagentur für Arbeit” (Federal Employment Agency) is requested by the “Ausländerbehörde” (Immigration Office).
In doing so, it checks the working conditions (for example, minimum wage, scope of work).
The granting of the employment permit is at the discretion of the foreigners authority.
If you have already been in Germany for 4 years, a general employment permit applies.
You then have full access to the labour market.
This means The approval of the “Bundesagentur für Arbeit” (Federal Employment Agency) is no longer necessary.
In principle, you do not need a work permit for school education.
Persons with a Duldung according to §60a AufenthG
There is a ban on working if:
They entered Germany with the motive of receiving asylum seekers' benefits.
Deportation is not possible for a reason for which the applicant is responsible and which is the cause of the impossibility of deportation.
Persons with a temporary residence permit §60b AufenthG
Toleration for persons "with unclear identity
For these persons, gainful employment is not allowed (work ban).
This toleration is granted to persons who have not fulfilledtheirobligations to cooperate.
Obtaining passports and clarifying identity
It is very important that you cooperate in obtaining your passport and clarifying your identity.
Otherwise, the Aliens' Registration Office or the Regional Council can issue you with a general ban on working under aliens' law.
If you have such a work ban, you cannot apply to the Aliens' Registration Office for admission to employment/training or continuation of existing employment.
If you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to contact your social services or the responsible integration management.

context:
What do I need in order to study?
If you want to study in Germany, you will need the following:
University entrance qualification
This is a school-leaving qualification that qualifies for university study, for example the Abitur or the higher education entrance qualification.
If you did not complete your school-leaving certificate in Germany, you must check whether you can study in Germany from abroad with this school-leaving certificate.
You can find further information here or here.
German language skills
Many courses of study (Bachelor, State Examination, Diploma) are in German.
Therefore, you usually need certain language certificates at B2/C1 level (European reference framework).
Some degree programmes (especially Master's and Doctorate) are also in English.

questions.question: What is the cost of German broadcasting fees?

context:
Broadcasting fees (GEZ)
What are broadcasting fees ()?
Germany has independent radio, television and online services from ARD, ZDF and Deutschlandradio.
They report free from economic and political influences.
For this, all people pay money together.
This is called “broadcasting fees”.
According to the law: A broadcasting fee must be paid for every home in Germany.
However, only one person per flat has to pay the broadcasting fee.
You can find more information here in different languages.
Do I have to pay as well?
Some people can be exempted from this payment.
For example, if you receive benefits under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act or other social benefits.
An application must be submitted for exemption from the broadcasting fee.
You can find the application for an exemption here.
General information and videos on the subject of broadcasting fees can be found here in several languages.

questions.question: What are the key elements of a work contract in Germany?
How can I terminate a work contract in Germany?
What does "Probezeit" mean in a German work contract?

context:
Contracts
In Germany, there are contracts for many things.
For example:
Renting an apartment (rental contract)
New job (employment contract)
New mobile phone (mobile phone contract)
Registering at the gym (membership contract)
If the contract is signed by two parties, it is legally binding.
Everything concluded in the contract must be complied with by the buyer and also by the trader.
For example, if you have a contract with the gym for 2 years, then you will also have to pay the fees for 2 years.
Therefore, you should consider whether you can pay for everything for this period.
Often, contracts also contain "small print".
This is usually written in small letters at the bottom of the contract.
It is essential that you always read this and agree to it before signing.
Donot allow yourself to be pressured into signing a contract.
You always have the right to read and check everything.
Ask if you can take the contract home with you if necessary.
Then you can read the contract in peace or have it translated.
You may also seek legal counsel or advice in the event of disagreement with the other party.
Termination
You must give written notice (usually 3 months before the end of the contract).
If you do not observe the notice period, the contract is often automatically renewed.
Mobile phone contract
There are two different mobile phone contracts in Germany.
Prepaid contract
The prepaid contract does not have a fixed contract term, but you have to top up your phone’s credit (money).
Term contract
The fixed-term contact has a minimum contract period.
Ask how long the contract lasts and check whether you can pay it for that long.
This contract is automatically renewed if you do not cancel.
If you do not want the contract to be automatically renewed, you must cancel in writing.
Pay attention to the notice period.

questions.question: What documents are needed for family reunification?
How long does the family reunification process take?
Who can I contact for help with family reunification in Germany?

context:
Reuniting Families
Do you and your family members not live in the same place or do you still have family members abroad?
Then, depending on the residence status , there are different ways to reunite the family.
If you already have a residence permit for purposes other than humanitarian reasons or if you are German, you can find more information at the Baden-Württemberg service portal.
Family reunion
If you live in Germany and already have a residence permit for humanitarian reasons, you may be able to bring direct family members (parents, children, spouse) from abroad.
This is only possible if you have been granted refugee status by the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF;
Bundesamt für Migration und Flüchtlinge).
To do this you must
file atimely report within 3 months of receiving your decision from the BAMF.
Your family members who are to join you in Germany must apply for a visa at the German mission abroad (e.g. embassy or consulate) in the respective country of their stay.
Where can I file a complaint within the time limit?
On the website of the German Foreign Office, the procedure for family reunification is explained to you and you can also directly file the timely application.
You can also find information on the page of the Integration Commissioner.
You can also get more information on family reunification at the responsible Bureau for Foreigners (Ausländerbehörde).
You can also get support for family reunification at the migration counselling centre of Caritas in the Rems-Murr district:
Migration counselling for adult immigrants
Contact details for migration counselling can be found here.
Family reunion
If you come to Germany as an asylum seeker, you will be assigned to a specific district in Germany (for example, the Rems-Murr district).
As a general rule, you must live there at least until the end of your asylum procedure.
Moving to be with family or for a job
However, under certain circumstances, you can change the location.
For example, if immediate family members (children, spouse, domestic partner, or parents) reside in other counties.
In order to be able to move in with your family, you must submit a application for reallocation to the competent foreigners authority.
If this application is approved, you may move.
If you already have a residence permit (Aufenthaltserlaubnis) and you get a condition of fixed abode (Wohnsitzauflage), you must look for an apartment within the specified location.
If you want to move to another place, you must also submita redistribution application or an application for cancellation of the residence requirement to the responsible foreigners authority.
This is possible, for example, because of a relationship or a job.
The application must be approved by the receiving immigration authority of the county or municipality to which you wish to move.

questions.question: What are the steps in the German asylum process?
How can I apply for asylum in Germany?
What documents do I need for my asylum interview?

context:
General information on the procedure
Are you registered in Germany and live in shared accommodation?
What happens next?
Here you will find a series of multilingual explanatory videos on the subject of asylum processes on the following topics:
Procedure of the asylum process
How to prepare for the hearing
What is an asylum decision and how does the appeal procedure work?
The BAMF has compiled a lot of information for you here.
Here you will find a film that explains the procedure.
The next steps are explained here:
1. Personal application for asylum
You apply for asylum at the BundesAmt für Migration und Flüchtlinge (BAMF).
Important: You can only submit your application in person, you cannot send this application by post.
You will receive the appointment and the responsible BAMF office with your proof of arrival.
If you did not get an appointment, ask your social worker.
2. First interview appointment (asylum application)
Go a few days before your 1. Appointment (asylum application, 1. Interview appointment) or your 2. Appointment (hearing, 2. Interview date) with your documents to your social workers in the accommodation.
If you have your 1. Interview at the BAMF, please remember to bring enough food with you.
There may be long waiting times.
As long as you are in the asylum procedure, you have a residence permit.
3. Personal hearing
The 2nd interview date is the hearing itself.
The BAMF decides on your application for asylum.
It will then send you a decision (Bescheid).
Show the notice to your social worker.
They will explain to you what was decided by the BAMF and what steps you can take.

context:
Important information for parents
Parents' evening
All parents are invited to a parents' evening.
You can communicate with other parents and the teacher and get a lot of information.
It is good if you take advantage of these meetings.
The dates will be communicated in a letter to parents.
It is important to read the letters to parents.
Parents' Council
There is a Parents' Council in every class.
This is elected by all parents during a parents' evening.
The tasks and rights of the Parents' Council are regulated by law.
The Parents' Council deals with problems that other parents tell them.
The Parents' Council represents the other parents before the school.
School social work
There are school social workers in many schools.
These can support children and young people at school.
School social workers advise and help with school and private problems, annoyances or other worries.
The service is voluntary and the school social workers work in confidence.
This means that they must not tell anyone about the problems.
Otherwise, there are also guidance counsellors or liaison teachers.
Check with your school.
Tutoring
If you have difficulties in some subjects at school and need additional support, you can register for tutoring.
The tutoring is carried out by a tutor and takes place outside the classroom.
The tutoring usually takes place in small groups or by way of individual supervision.
You can repeat content here or get extra tasks to practice.
Tutoring costs money.
If you are Entitled to BuTthe costs for tutoring can be paid under certain conditions (confirmation from the school that your child urgently needs tutoring).
You have to fill out a BuT application.
If you need help finding tutoring, ask your integration manager, social counselling, youth migration coun selling or migration counselling.

context:
Domestic violence
Domestic violence includes all forms of physical, sexual and/or psychological violence between persons in a mostly domestic community.
It does not matter whether the persons live together in a marriage, a registered partnership or just because, which sexual orientation is present or whether it is a community of several generations.
The scene of the crime can also be outside the home, for example on the street, in the shop and at the workplace, but often the home itself is the scene of the crime.
No one has to endure when she or he
is humiliated, insulted, beaten or threatened,
is prevented from leaving the house,
from meeting family, relatives, girlfriends or friends,
is forced to have sex,
Separation or wishes for separation are not accepted,
is persecuted, harassed or terrorised.
Victim counselling Rems-Murr district
The counselling service is confidential, free of charge and personalised to you.
The victim counselling counsels persons of all genders and ages.
info@opferberatung-rems-murr.de
opferberatung-rems-murr.de
Helpline for women experiencing violence
Women affected by violence can find support at the help line.
At the request of a caller, the counsellors will call in an interpreter in the required language within one minute.
Free, anonymous and confidential counselling is available in 18 foreign languages.
You can receive advice by phone, chat or email.

context:
What do I have to do when my child is sick?
If your child is ill or cannot go to school for other important reasons, you must report him or her as sick at school.
Please call the school before the start of the lesson .
Most schools also expect a written note excusing the child.
This is a letter from the parents.
The written excuse must often be received by the school within three days.
If your child is ill for a longer period of time , he/she needs a doctor's certificate .
The certificate must also be handed in at school.
It is best to ask the secretary's office what the school needs.
If your child does not come to school without a telephone or written excuse or a medical certificate, the school must look for your child.
If necessary, the school will even search for your child with the help of the police.
You may then have to pay a fine.

questions.question: How do I register for German taxes as a newcomer?
What social security benefits am I eligible for in Germany?
How much income tax should I expect to pay in Germany?

context:
Taxes and social security payments
Every employee in Germany pays a part of his or her wage as taxes and social security contributions.
Self-employed persons must also pay taxes.
Income tax
Income tax is a contribution to financing federal, state and local government spending.
With the money from taxes, streets and schools are built or social benefits are financed, for example.
If you have an employer (i.e. are “angestellt”), you will receive the net sum of your salary from your employer – in other words, your taxes have already been deducted.
If you are self-employed, you are responsible for your own income tax
Tax ID number
All working persons receive a “Tax ID number” when they start work.
The tax ID is a 11-digit number and is used for income tax.
It is valid for the whole of your life.
Children born in Germany receive a letter with their personal tax ID within three months after the birth;
this is required to apply for child benefit (Kindergeld) for example.
If you work in Germany, you will need the number again and again, for example, for your employer.
If you do not know the number, you can ask for it personally at the Meldebehörde (registration office) or in writing from the Bundesamt für Steuern (federal tax office).
Tax return
In the annual tax return, you can claim various expenses from the Tax Office to reduce the amount of tax you pay.
You can receive refunds or you may have to pay additional payments to the Tax Office.
Many people are obliged to complete a tax return;
it is best to ask the Finanzamt (tax office) if this applies to you.
If you need help with your tax return, you should contact your local taxpayer’s advice centre.
If you have further questions, the tax office can also help you.
Social security payments
Social security contributions are the contributions to social insurance that employees have to deduct from their gross monthly wage in addition to taxes - this is legally obligatory and is automatically calculated by the employer.
Part of social insurance is also paid by the employer.
The social security payments finance the German social insurance system.
If people can't find work, or are no longer able to work, their key living costs will still be covered.
Ultimately, social contributions serve the personal security of each and every individual - for example, if you become unemployed and have previously paid into unemployment insurance for a certain period of time, you are entitled to unemployment benefit I. Likewise, with your monthly contribution to pension insurance, you acquire a right to receive a state pension in old age.
The contributions to social insurance are made up of payments towards:
Pension insurance
Unemployment insurance
Health Insurance
Long-term care insurance
The amount depends on your individual income.
The contributions are automatically deducted from your gross salary.
There are exceptions for foreign workers, for example if they are sent by a foreign company to Germany, work in several countries or are self-employed or affected by other exemptions.
To receive a permanent residence, it’s a requirement that you have paid contributions for at least 60 months into pension insurance.
This also applies to self-employed people.
There are also exemptions here.
‘Sozialversicherungsnummer’ (social security number)
Deutsche Rentenversicherung (the German state pension insurance company) automatically sends you your social security number the first time you take up employment in Germany.
If you lose this number you can request to have it sent to you again:
Telephone number of the Deutsche Rentenversicherung:
Additional information: German Pension Insurance

questions.question: What should be included in a German employment contract?
How can I negotiate my employment contract in Germany?
What does "Probezeit" mean in a German employment contract?

context:
Employment contract
Anyone who starts a job gets an employment contract.
The employment contract regulates the most important conditions of an employment relationship such as:
Working hours
Holiday
The amount of salary and
Periods of notice
Both sides - workers and employers - must abide by these agreements.
As the contract becomes legally valid with your signature, you should only sign it when you fully understand the content.
If you later discover that you have signed a contract with which you do not agree after all, you can have the clauses reviewed.
A lawyer can help you with this, for example.
You can get further support here.
Note:
An employment contract can also be established verbally or tacitly by conclusive conduct!
If you have worked, your employer has to pay you for it, even if there is no written employment contract (yet in place)!
Types of contracts
Permanent job contract (Unbefristeter Arbeitsvertrag)
There is usually a probationary period of three or six months.
During this period, both the employer and the employee may terminate an employment relationship at short notice within two weeks.
At the end of the probationary period, a permanent employment relationship begins with longer protection against dismissal.
Working hours are usually up to 40 hours a week.
Fixed-term employment contract (Befristeter Arbeitsvertrag)
The employment ends at the agreed time, without the need for notice of resignation.

The specialist unit Migrant Economy of the IQ Network also provides information and support to people from abroad in setting up their own business.

questions.question: Who is eligible to vote in Germany?
How can a newcomer register to vote?
What documents are needed to vote in Germany?

context:
Right to vote
People in Germany have the right to vote.
They are allowed to vote for politicians.
That is written in a law.
And these are the most important elections in Germany:
Landtag election
You elect politicians for the Landtag in your federal state.
The Landtag decides things for the federal state.
A new Landtag is always elected after 5 years.
Election to the Bundestag
You elect politicians for the Bundestag.
The Bundestag decides things for the whole of Germany.
A new Bundestag is always elected after 4 years.
European election
You elect politicians for the European Parliament.
The European Parliament decides things for all countries in the European Union.
A new European Parliament is always elected after 5 years.
In Germany there are 2 different electoral rights:
1. the active right to vote
You have a German passport.
And you are 18 years or older.
Then you have the active right to vote.
This means that you can vote.
For example, in these elections:
Bundestag election
Landtag election
Local elections
Mayor election
Senior citizens' council election
2. the right to stand for election
You have a German passport.
And you are 18 years or older.
Then you have the right to stand for election.
This means: You can be elected by other people.
You can then work as a politician.
For example, you then work
For the German Bundestag
For the Landtag
For local government
For the Foreigners' Advisory Council
You are an EU citizen.
You may then vote in Germany in these elections:
Local election
European election

questions.question: What unemployment benefits can I apply for in Germany?
How can I apply for unemployment benefits as a refugee?
What documents do I need for unemployment benefits application?

context:
Unemployment benefit
You will receiveunemployment benefit if you lose your job.
You must have worked in Germany for at least 12 months in the last 30 months.
There are other conditions under certain circumstances.
The Federal Employment Agency will decide whether you receive unemployment benefit.
1. register as a jobseeker
You have been made redundant, you have given notice or your temporary employment contract is coming to an end.
The Employment Agency will support you in your search for new employment.
They will also work with you to determine whether you are entitled to financial support.
It is important that you register as a jobseeker immediately.
Register as a jobseeker at least 3 months before the end of your employment relationship.
If you only find out later, register as a jobseeker no later than 3 days later.
You can do this in various ways:
On site at your local employment agency
by telephone at
online at https://www.arbeitsagentur.de/
2. register as unemployed in person
You must register as unemployed in person at your local employment agency on your first day without work at the latest.
This is the prerequisite for receiving unemployment benefit.
3. complete the application for unemployment benefit
Apply for unemployment benefit online.
Alternatively, you can obtain an application form from your local employment agency to submit the application in writing.
You can obtain further informationhere.

questions.question: What are the women's rights in Germany?
How can I report discrimination against women?
What does "gender equality" mean in Germany?

context:
Equal rights for men and women
Women and men have the same rights.
Women and men have the same duties.
This is reflected in the laws and in daily life.
This means, for example:
Girls and boys go to school together and receive the same lessons.
They take part in sports classes together.
Women are allowed to study or learn a profession.
In principle, all professions are open to women.
Women assume responsibility in society, for example as policewomen, doctors, teachers or in offices and authorities.
Their instructions must be followed.
Women decide for themselves what work they want to do.
They can dispose of the money they earn themselves.
Women do not have to ask their husbands, parents or other family members for permission to work, open a bank account or sign contracts.
Women are allowed to dress the way they want.
Women decide for themselves if, when and whom they want to marry.
Mothers are especially protected.
They do not have to and are not allowed to work for six weeks before and eight weeks after giving birth.
They may not be dismissed because of their maternity.
The tasks and roles in the family are not prescribed.
Women participate in public life.
They attend cultural, political or sporting events, restaurants and bars.
Women can vote and be elected to political offices.
Women and men are equal in inheritance rights, daughters as well as sons.
Sexual touching, comments or solicitations are only allowed if all parties agree.
A "stop" or "no" must be respected at all costs.
This is not allowed in Germany, for example:
Any form of violence towards women, even in marriage.
No one may be sexually harassed.
Rape, even within marriage, is punished.
No one may be forced to marry.
Coercion to marry by force or threat is punished.

questions.question: How do I register the birth of my child in Germany?
What documents are needed for child care benefits?
Where can I find information on child development programs?

context:
After giving birth
Registration registry office
Newborn children must be registered with the “Standesamt” (Registry Office) and, if necessary, your accommodation management team.
The maternity clinic reports the birth to the Registry Office.
There you will receive the birth certificate for your child together with your ID card, the birth certificate from the clinic and, if available, your marriage certificate.
Please submit only original documents.
For documents in a foreign language, an officially certified German translation is required.
If you live in shared accommodation, please provide a copy of the birth certificate to your accommodation facility management so that your child can be registered.
Find a paediatrician
When the baby is born, it is advisable to make an appointment immediately with a paediatrician for a U3 examination.
The U3 examination is one of 12 preventive examinations for children.
It is carried out between the 3rd and 8th grade.
Week of life.
These examinations are very important and must be carried out.
It is advisable to make an appointment as soon as possible, as long waiting times are to be expected when appointments are made.
Here you can find a brochure on the subject of U-examination in different languages.
Financial support
Those who have no or only a low income can apply for unemployment benefit II or assistance under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act (AsylbLG).
After the twelfth week of pregnancy, theJob Centre or the Social Welfare Office then pay mothers-to-be additional needs and the initial equipment for pregnancy and baby.
Claim child benefit
All children in Germany are entitled to a child benefit from birth until the age of 18.
(or even later, in exceptional cases).
Your child must live in your household and be cared for by yourself.
You can get more information here.

context:
LGBTIQ* counselling centres
In Germany, people of different religions, genders, origins and political views live together peacefully and enjoy the same rights.
The same applies to people of different sexual orientations or gender identities: lesbians, gays, bisexuals, transgender people, intersex people and queer people, or LGBTIQ for short, have the same rights in Germany as other people.
In addition to the two genders "male" and "female", Germany has recently introduced the third gender entry "diverse".
Transgender people in Germany can have their gender entry and name changed.
Women in Germany are allowed to love and marry other women, men other men.
Many LGBTIQ* people have fled to Germany because they were persecuted in their home country.
If you have fled and are lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender or intersex, you can find support, social contacts and information from many LGBTIQ organisations in Germany.

The Regenbogen Refugium of Weissenburg e. V. offers meetings and networking opportunities for LGBTTIQ refugees and their supporters.
Counselling for LGBTTIQ refugees takes place twice a month in cooperation with amnesty international Stuttgart.
The Turkish community in Baden-Württemberg (tgbw) offers "Specialist counselling for gender and cultural diversity in Stuttgart".
It is aimed specifically at LGBTIQ* people with an international history and/or experiences of racism.

questions.question: What is the minimum school age in Germany?
Is school attendance mandatory for adults?
How long does primary education last in Germany?

context:
Compulsory schooling
Compulsory schooling
In Germany, attending school is compulsory.
This means that in Germany, all children from the ages of 6 up to (and including) 18 must attend school.
The parents or guardians of the children have the duty to ensure that the children attend school.
Compulsory education includes:
participation in classes
participation in the compulsory events of the school
compliance with the school rules
You will be fined for unexcused absence.
In the worst case, the police will also visit you.
In addition, the “Jugendamt” (Youth Welfare Office) can then also be called in.
Are you new to Germany?
Your child can go to school from the first day.
If you have already been in Germany for 6 months, your child must go to school.
School attendance is compulsory after 6 months.

questions.question: How can I apply for a German pension?

context:
Pension
For many people, the question arises: What happens if I can no longer work in my old age?
For this purpose, Germany has the social security system of the German pension insurance (DRV).
The website of the German pension insurance offers a lot of information and can answer some questions about pensions
Deutsche Rentenversicherung
In principle, the pension is paid for by contributions from compulsory insurance jobs.
As a rule, halfof the contribution is paid by the employer and half by the employee.
If you are now in a position to claim a pension, you must apply for it.
The pension is not paid automatically.
You apply for this at least 3 months before you plan to retire.
This makes the transition from employment to retirement easier.
You can find the nearest advice centre on pension insurance here.
There you can get more detailed information about your model of pension and other benefit.
However, the pension insurance does not only pay a pension, but also provides other benefits.
This includes, for example, rehabilitation measures in order to be able to work again.
It is important that the later pension benefit does not decrease as a result.
It may even increase if such a measure keeps you fit for work for longer.

context:
Things to know about the Rems-Murr district
Numbers, data, facts
The Rems-Murr district is located in the Stuttgart region of Baden-Württemberg.
The district takes its name from the rivers Rems and Murr.
With an area of 858 km² and a population of 426,635, the Rems-Murr-Kreis is one of the larger administrative districts.
A total of 31 towns and municipalities belong to the Rems-Murr district.
Among them are the six large district towns of Backnang, Fellbach, Schorndorf, Waiblingen, Weinstadt and Winnenden.
Economy
The Rems-Murr district is an attractive business location for both large companies and small and medium-sized enterprises.
A special feature is its commercial and industrial structure.
There are numerous large companies in the Rems-Murr district, such as Stihl (power saws), Bosch (household appliances) and Kärcher (household appliances).
About 15 percent of the employees work in the mechanical engineering sector.
This is a state record in Baden-Württemberg.

questions.question: How can I apply for a residence permit in Germany?
What are my rights as a refugee in Germany?

context:
Personal freedom
All adults are allowed to decide about themselves and their own lives.
No matter whether man or woman, young or old, with or without disabilities, no matter what skin colour or religious affiliation.
All people are allowed to do what they want as long as they abide by the law and do not restrict others in their freedom.
That means, for example:
All people are allowed to decide what they want to wear.
Women, for example, are allowed to decide whether they want to wear trousers, dresses, long or short skirts, tight or loose clothing or a headscarf.
Men are allowed to decide, for example, whether to wear a suit and tie, T-shirt and jeans, turban, hat or beard.
All people are allowed to eat what they want and what they like.
The decision whether to eat meat (including pork or beef) is made by people all by themselves.
There are no universally valid or religiously based food regulations from the state.
The consumption of alcohol is permitted for adults.
For children and adolescents, the consumption of alcohol is prohibited.
Every woman and every man may decide for themselves whether and whom they wish to marry.
Every woman and every man may divorce.

A person's decision to use contraception must be respected.
Same-sex partnerships are accepted.

The rights of a civil partnership are similar to those of a marriage between a man and a woman.
Everyone decides for themselves how and where they want to live.
For people in the asylum process, this right may be restricted until an asylum application is accepted.
Sexual acts between adults may only take place with mutual consent.

Private property is allowed for every man and woman in Germany.
It is allowed to own a house or a plot of land.
Many companies are privately owned.
Women and men have equal rights when it comes to inheritance.

One's own freedom ends where it infringes on the freedom or human dignity of others or violates laws.

questions.question: What happens if my asylum application is approved?
What are the consequences of a rejected asylum application?
Can I appeal if my asylum application is denied?

context:
Decisions of the BAMF (Federal Office for Migration and Refugees)
The decision from the BAMF (Federal Office for Migration and Refugees)
Some time after your hearing (interview) at the BAMF you will receive your decision by post (yellow envelope).
The decision states how your asylum procedure was decided.
After receiving the decision, show it immediately to your social care provider.
They will explain to you what was decided by the BAMF and what steps you can take.
Important!
You have a period of 2 weeks to file a complaint against the decision.
The deadline begins on the date printed on the yellow envelope.
There are the following decisions of the asylum procedure:
Right of asylum – Article 16a of the Basic Law (GG):
Residence permit for 3 years
Settlement permit possible after 3 years at the earliest (prerequisites are checked individually)
unlimited labour market access
Entitlement to family reunion
Granting asylum/refugee status § 3 German Asylum Law (AsylG):
Residence permit for 3 years (thereafter extension under certain circumstances)
Settlement permit possible after 3 years at the earliest (prerequisites are checked individually)
unlimited labour market access
Entitlement to family reunion
Granting subsidiary protection § 4 German Asylum Law (AsylG):
Residence permit for 1 year (2 more years for each extension)
Settlement permit possible after 5 years at the earliest (prerequisites are checked individually)
Employment permitted, self-employment only with permission from foreigners authority
Possibility of family reunification to be examined individually
Determination of a national ban on deportation § 60 (5) and (7) Residence Act (AufenthG):
Residence permit for 1 year (with extension for 1 further year each)
Settlement permit possible after 5 years at the earliest (prerequisites are checked individually)
Employment possible with permission from the foreigners authority
Family reunion not possible
An asylum application was rejected?
There are two types of rejection:
The asylum application is rejected as inadmissiblebecause another country is responsible for processing the asylum application (Dublin procedure).
This is the case if you have already applied for asylum in a different country or had your fingerprints taken there.
Deportation to this country is threatened (example: Italy).
The asylum application is rejected (national procedure).
Deportation to your country of origin will be imposed.
In these two cases, you are legally obliged to leave Germany and must leave again.
As long as your deportation is not possible, you will be granted a " Duldung“ (toleration) under certain circumstances.
A Duldung is not a residence title.
The Regional Council is responsible for tolerated persons.
They also oversee and carry out deportation.
What can I do if I do not want to be deported but no longer have any options to stay in Germany?
If you decide to leave voluntarily, you can receive financial support for your new start in your home country.

questions.question: When should I contact the police in Germany?

How can I find my local police station in Germany?

context:
Police
The police are there to protectus from danger.
They also investigate and solve crimes.
The police have nothing to do with the secret service or politicians.
There is an emergency?
Then you can reach the police at any time under 110.
The call is free of charge.
There are laws which govern what the police can and can’t do.
For example, in order to search a house, they need a warrant from a judge.
Unless there is great danger to a person in the home.
When should I call the police?
You or another person are in danger?
You have witnessed a crime?
Then call the police.
Burglary, theft, arson and damage to property are also included.
Sexual abuse, assault or threats are also the responsibility of the police.
Also in the case of domestic violenceyou should call the police.
You can also call the police for a so-called administrative offence .
For example, if someone does not comply with quiet times and plays loud music at night.
If you dial the emergency number 110, the police will be with you as soon as possible.
Also, if you notice political or religious radicalisation of young adults in your environment, you can report this to the police.
However, you can also contact the counselling centre for radicalisation for this:

questions.question: What is vocational training toleration for migrants?
Who is eligible for vocational training toleration in Germany?
How can I apply for vocational training toleration as a migrant?

context:
Training toleration (§60c)
Duration: "Guaranteed" suspension of deportation for the duration of vocational training
Perspective: The transition to a residence permit after successful completion of the training is possible, provided that the requirements are then met.
For whom is toleration of vocational training possible?
Tolerated persons (§ 60a AufenthG) who have already started training during the asylum procedure
Tolerated persons who want to start an apprenticeship: these persons must have been in possession of a toleration certificate according to § 60a for three months
In order to get a vocational training tolerance, you have to submit the training contract to the “Regierungspräsidium” (Regional Council).
The application via the Foreigners' Registration Office is made with additional documents.
Requirements:
Qualified vocational training: Training in a state-recognised or comparably regulated training occupation
Standard training duration at least two years
In the case of training for assistants or helpers, qualified training in a so-called bottleneck occupation must be able to be followed up and a training place commitment must be available for this (e.g. geriatric care and nursing assistance)
The registration of the vocational training in the register of vocational training relationships is usually kept by the IHK or HWK.
clarified identity
The clarified identity may be waived if all reasonable and necessary steps to clarify the identity have been taken within the respective applicable time limit and the identity is/was still not clarified.
The Regierungspräsidium decides whether the postponement of deportation due to vocational training (Ausbildungsduldung) is granted despite the unclear identity.
With an introductory qualification (EQ), you do not get a training permit (Ausbildungsduldung).
But the EQ, i.e. a longer internship in a company, still offers advantages: Preparation for vocational training and the possibility of an accompanying language course!
Contact
If you have any questions, please contact the foreigners authorityresponsible for you.

questions.question: What types of vocational training are available in Germany for newcomers?
How can I apply for vocational training programs in Germany?
What qualifications do I need to meet for specific career options in Germany?

context:
Why do an apprenticeship?
In Germany, it is a great advantage if you have a vocational qualification before you go to work.
With a vocational qualification, you earn more money on average over the course of your life, become unemployed less often and have fixed-term contracts less often than if you were looking for work without a vocational qualification.
In principle, training can begin at any time.
The regular start of training is 1 August or 1 September each year.
In some professions, it is also possible to start on 1 February or 1 March.
If the start of training differs from this, the respective vocational school should be consulted.
The duration of the vocational training depends on the type of job.
It usually lasts 3 years.
At the end of the training period you take a final exam.
If you pass the exam, you can work in this profession.
There is no age limit to start vocational training.
You can also do part-time vocational training.
A part-time vocational training programme lasts the same length of time as a normal, full-time one – but less time is spent at the company each day or week.
Successfully completed vocational training opens up many options on the labour market to you.
You can also take up a course of study after completing your training.
An Internship is useful to get an insight into a profession.
You can find out whether you like the profession.
You can also improve your German language skills.
Whether you are allowed to do an apprenticeship depends on your residence status.
There are around 400 apprenticeship occupationsin Germany.
If you are interested in vocational training, you can find further information and contact persons at Training in Germany (dual and full-school).
As a teenager and young adult, you have to go to vocational school .
This is true if you are undergoing vocational training, but also in other cases.
The vocational schools in the Rems-Murr district also offer various educational and counselling services to prepare you for vocational training or for starting a career.
The youth vocational assistance or AVdual counsellors can advise you on this.
Outside of the vocational schools, the HWK, the IHK and the employment promotion companies also provide support when starting a career and in the first few months of training.

questions.question: What types of family planning services are available in Germany?
How can I access free or low-cost contraception options?
Who can I consult for family planning advice in Germany?

context:
Sexual counselling and contraception
Family planning
Everyone decides for themselves how and with whom they want to have sex.
In the same way, you decide for yourself whether, when and how many children you want to have.
You can also say that you have the right to family planning and sexual self-determination.
You can find multilingual information on the subject of sexuality at
www.zanzu.de
Sexual counselling
At a sexual counselling session, you can talk about your sexuality in a protected environment.
Questions about your body, sexual orientation, but also experiences of sexual violence can be discussed.
You can find more information here: www.zanzu.de
Counselling centre
Pro Familia Waiblingen
waiblingen@profamilia.de
Contraception
There are various methods if you don't want to get pregnant or want to prevent infection with sexually transmitted diseases.
For example, barrier methods such as the condom, or methods with hormones such as the pill.
You can find multilingual information on the subject of contraception at
www.zanzu.de
www.profamilia.de
A condom protects against sexually transmitted diseases such as HIV.
You can find out about contraceptive methods from a gynaecologist.
Emergency contraception:
If you have sexual intercourse without contraception, there is a possibility that you will become pregnant, even if you do not want to.
Mistakes can also happen when using contraception.
Then you will become pregnant despite using contraception.
In these cases, you can take the "morning after pill".
You must take it as soon as possible, preferably in the first twelve hours after sexual intercourse.
You can buy the morning-after pill from a pharmacy without a prescription.
You can get advice on this at a pharmacy or from a doctor.

questions.question: What kind of work permit do I need in Germany?
How can I apply for a residence permit in Germany?
What documents are required for a work permit in Germany?

context:
May I work with a residence permit?
Permission to work as an asylum seeker with a residence permit depends on this,
whether you live in an initial reception centre or have already been placed outside the initial reception centre
how many months you have already been in Germany.
They still live in the initial reception centre
No employment permit can be issued during thefirst nine months after the asylum application is filed.
During this time, your identity document will contain the sentence: "Gainful employment not permitted".
After the ninth month from the date of application for asylum, there is an entitlement to the issuance of an employment permit.
Your identity document says "Gainful employment only permitted with the permission of the foreigners authority."
You must complete and sign the job description and declaration of employmentand hand it in to the Aliens' Registration Office.
You no longer live in the initial reception centre
If you are in Germany for less than 3 months, you are not allowed to work.
If you have been in Germany for 4-9 months or longer, you can apply for an employment permit at the Aliens' Registration Office (see above).
The decision is taken at the discretion of the relevant authority.
From the 10.
Month you can apply for an employment permit.
This is then no longer a discretionary decision, because you are entitled to it.
A general employment permit applies from4 years in Germany.
You then have full access to the labour market.
This means The approval of the “Bundesagentur für Arbeit” (Federal Employment Agency) is no longer necessary.
But this must be applied for at the “Ausländerbehörde” (Immigration Office).
It will then be noted in your residence permit.
If you have any further questions, please contact your social services or integration management.

questions.question: Which job-related German courses can I take?
Where can I find and sign up for these job-related German courses?
What qualifications or skills will I gain after completing a job-related German course at level B2?

context:
Vocational Language Courses (DeuFöV)
Job-related German courses help to further improve one's German skills, for example after having already attended an integration course.
You can attend the so-called DeuFöV courses while you are working, undergoing training or a vocational qualification measure or as preparation for starting a career in Germany.
The basic structure of the professional language courses is the basic course.
A basic distinction is made between three types: B1 to B2, B2 to C1 and C1 to C2.
The modules each comprise 300 teaching units.
However, there are also special modules that only require speaking level A2 or B1.
Additional special modules are specifically adapted to specific occupational groups.
Who can participate?
You must meet the following requirements to participate in the professional language course:
They have a migration background and a need for further language training.
This is the case with immigrants from third countries, EU citizens and Germans with a migration background.
You have already completed an integration course and/or already speak German at A1, A2, B1, B2 or C1 level according to the Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR) for languages.
In order to attend courses with a target language level below B2, prior attendance of an integration course with a passed and failed German test for immigrants is required.
You must be registered as a job seeker and/or usually receive benefits according to SGB II ("Hartz IV") or SGB III (unemployment benefit).
You are looking for a training position or are already in training.
You are currently going through the recognition procedure for your vocational qualification or training certificate.
Participation as an employee
If you are already in employment, you can take part in the professional language course.
The prerequisite is that you do not yet have sufficient language skills to master your future everyday working life.
Cost of participation
Participation in the professional language course is generally free of charge.
If your taxable annual income is over €20,000, you pay a cost contribution of €2.42 per teaching unit (50 per cent of the cost reimbursement rate).
This is a total of 1,452 € for a course with 600 teaching units.
The payment of the cost contribution can also be made by the employer.
Upon successful completion of the examination, a refund of 50 per cent of the cost contribution can be applied for.
Eligibility
As a rule, the employment agencies and job centresdecide on eligibility.
Contact your counsellor here.
They will also know which language schools offer courses and whether special courses are possible for you.
If you are already working or in a training relationship or in the recognition procedure and do not receive benefits under SGB II or SGB III, you can apply directly to the BAMF for entitlement to participate.
Here you can search for relevant courses in the Rems-Murr district.

questions.question: What are my rights regarding personal safety in Germany?
Who can I contact if my physical integrity is threatened?
How can I report a violation of my personal rights in Germany?

context:
Freedom from violence/physical integrity
Everyone has the right to live without violence.
This means that all people have the right to life and physical integrity.
This is understood to meanboth the physical and mental health of a person.
This also applies in the private sphere.
This means, for example:
Conflicts should be resolved without violence.
Anyone who needs help in case of danger or conflict can call the police.
All instructions of the police are to be followed.
Vigilante justice is not permitted.
If one's rights have been violated, a state court decides.
The state must act non-violently.
It may only use force in exceptional cases when all other means have been exhausted.
There is no death penalty or corporal punishment, torture is prohibited.
This is not permitted in Germany, for example:
To physically abuse, injure or kill another person.
This also applies within the family, at school and on the street.
Participating in a brawl that results in people being killed or seriously physically injured.
Blood revenge and murder in the name of honour.
Violence against women and children always and everywhere.
Human trafficking, slavery and the coercion of prostitution.
The sewing up, circumcision or mutilation of female genitalia.
Sewing up, cutting or mutilating the female genitals is also called female genital mutilation or circumcision .
In Germany, this is a punishable offence.
Information on domestic violence can be found here.

context:
Child benefit and parental allowance
Child benefit
All children in Germany are entitled to child benefit from birth until they reach the age of 18.
In individual cases, this can also be up to the age of 25.
Your child must live in your household and be cared for by you.
Child benefit is only paid to one person at a time, usually one parent.
If you have several children, the individual amounts are paid out as one sum.
Often, you will receive at least € 250 per month for each child.
If you have several children, the number of children determines the amount of child benefit.
From the third child onwards, you are entitled to more child benefit.
How do I get child benefit?
You must submit an application to the Family Benefits Office (Familienkasse) of the Federal Employment Agency (Bundesagentur für Arbeit).
Please also contact your benefit provider (job centre or district office) for more information.
The application and further information on child benefit
Note for asylum seekers: You cannot receive child benefit during the asylum procedure.
This is only possible after you have received a positive decision from the BAMF.
Responsible for the Rems-Murr district: Familienkasse Baden-Württemberg-Ost (family benefits office).
Parental allowance
Many parents want to take care of their child after the birth.
To do so, you do not work for a certain period of time.
Or you only work part-time.
If you have applied for parental allowance, you can get at least 300 € every month.
But it can also be more.
You usually get parental allowance for 12 months.
But it can also be longer.
You get parental allowance if you have a residence and stay in Germany.
You need a residence permit.
You must live together with your child.
The application and further information on parental allowance
Apply for parental allowance digitally

questions.question: Which vaccinations are required in Germany?

What does "vaccination protection" mean?

context:
Protection provided by vaccination
Many diseases are caused by bacteria or viruses.
Vaccinations are a good measure to protect yourself.
If many people are vaccinated against a certain disease, further spread is prevented.
In Germany, there are recommendations on when which vaccinations should be given.
Several vaccinations are necessary against some diseases.
The recommended vaccinations are paid for by the health insurance companies.
If you have a vaccination document, you should show it when you visit your doctor.
Then they can decide which vaccinations are required.
If you do not have one, your doctor will issue you with a "vaccination card".
Keep this document in a safe place.
You should take it with you to every doctor's appointment.
Get your children vaccinated too.
This will protect you and your family from diseases such as measles, rubella, polio, tetanus, whooping cough or influenza.
Here you will find multilingual information on which vaccinations are recommended by the Standing Committee on Vaccination (STIKO).
Measles vaccination
Important!
Your child must be vaccinated against measles when attending a day care centre or school.
The measles protection law in Germany states that all children over the age of one must have two measles vaccinations when they enter kindergarten, day care or school.
Here you will find information in several languages.

Dear citizens,
No matter whether you immigrated some time ago or very recently: I would like to welcome you to the Rems-Murr district!
Around 430,000 inhabitants live in the Rems-Murr district in a total of 31 towns and municipalities.

questions.question: What are the requirements for obtaining a settlement permit in Germany?
How long do I need to have lived in Germany to be eligible for a settlement permit?
Do I need to speak German to get a settlement permit in Germany?

context:
Settlement permit
Duration: unlimited, validity of the eAT (electronic residence permit) corresponds to the duration of the passport
Authorised for any gainful employment, including self-employment.
Requirements:
Third-country nationals who have resided in Germany for an uninterrupted period of five years with a residence permit
Securing their livelihood (securing their livelihood)
60 months of pension insurance contributions
Knowledge of the legal and social order (orientation course)
Sufficient living space (for each family member over the age of six, a living space of at least 12 m² must be demonstrated.
For each family member between the ages of two and six, 10m² should be sufficient;
children aged 0-2 are not included)
Secured livelihood: Your livelihood is secured if you can cover your living expenses and sufficient health insurance cover without recourse to public funds.
Special standard:
Settlement permit (§ 26 (3) AufenthG) for persons entitled to asylum and refugees under the Geneva Refugee Convention
The settlement permit is issued after three years if the following requirements are met:
The German language is "mastered" (C1)
The livelihood is largely secured (at least 75%)
The BAMF has not notified you in accordance with Section 73 (2a) of the Asylum Act that the conditions for revocation or withdrawal have been met
Basic knowledge of the legal and social order and living conditions in Germany (orientation course)
Sufficient living space (see above)
After 5 years, the settlement permit will be issued if the following requirements are met:
Sufficient knowledge of the German language (A2)
The livelihood is predominantly secured (at least 51%)
There are no requirements for revocation or cancellation of the asylum decision
Orientation course
Sufficient living space (see above)

Clubs in the Rems-Murr district
Clubs are of great social importance in Germany.
They offer people the opportunity to realise common goals and improve their language skills.
These goals can be of different kinds: sporting activity, leisure activities, commitment to the needy and disadvantaged, protecting nature or socialising with like-minded people.
There are many sports clubs in the Rem-Murr district for a wide variety of sports.
But there are also music clubs and other hobby clubs.
Normally you have to pay an annual membership fee to be a member.
However, you can obtain more detailed information about this directly from the club.

context:
Unintended pregnancy
You can use contraceptive methods to avoid an unwanted pregnancy.
If you are not planning to become pregnant, it is particularly important that you seek help and advice.
You should find out about different options.
You can find multilingual information here.
Termination of pregnancy
You can terminate the pregnancy with an abortion.
Termination of pregnancy is possible up to the twelfth week of pregnancy.
Before that, you must go to a pregnancy conflict counselling centre and have a consultation.
Pregnancy conflict counselling:
pro familia Waiblingen
waiblingen@profamilia.de
Rems-Murr district office
schwanger@rems-murr-kreis.de
The help hotline "Pregnant women in need - anonymous and safe" at
Counselling is available in many languages with the help of an interpreter.
You can also get information about a pregnancy counselling centre near you.
They will provide you with anonymous and free counselling and support you in all further steps.
There is a brochure in several languages on the subject of abortion.
Adoption
You can continue the pregnancy and give the baby up for adoption.
In Germany, women can have their baby in hospital without having to give their name.
After the birth, the mother leaves the hospital.
The baby is given up for adoption after a certain period of time.
You can find helpful information under "Confidential counselling and birth".
Baby hatch
It is also possible to hand over the child to the baby hatch.
The baby hatch offers help for mothers and their newborn babies who find themselves in extremely difficult and seemingly hopeless situations.
There is a baby hatch in Stuttgart.

context:
Self-help groups
What are self-help groups?
Self-help groups are self-organised groups of people who have the same problem or illness and want to do something together to get better.
What happens in a self-help group?
The participants exchange ideas and information.
Examples: How do other sufferers deal with the illness or problem in certain situations in everyday life?
What information is available on certain illnesses or problems?
The participants support and help each other.
Self-help groups are no substitute for medicine or therapy.
But they are a very good and important addition.
What is said in the self-help groups is confidential.
Everything is voluntary, nobody is forced.
Which groups are there?
Here you can find out more about the self-help groups in the Rems-Murr district.

context:
Work permit
If you have a residence permit or proof of arrival, your access to the labour market is restricted.
Self-employment is generally not permitted.
To work as an employee, you must apply for a work permit at your foreigners authority before you start working.
Asylum seekers can get a work permit if they have already been in Germany for 3 months and no longer have to live in an initial reception centre.
If you still have to live in an initial reception centre, you can get a work permit after 6 months if you have minor children.
If you do not have minor children and are still living in an initial reception centre, you can get a work permit after 9 months .
You can find out more about safe countries of origin in our chapter "Safe countries of origin".
Important: Your work permit is not valid in general, but for a very specific job.
To do this, the future employer must fill in a form about the conditions of the job, and you yourself must fill in the "Application for permission to work".
Documents
Certificate of employment and earnings (PDF file)(for employees;
to be completed by the employer)

Skilled workers with a German university degree
Recognised foreign university degree
A comparable foreign university degree.
With the EU Blue Card, third-country nationals can obtain a residence permit in EU member states for the purpose of employment appropriate to their qualifications.
Prerequisites:
Concrete job offer that corresponds to the qualification

Annual gross salary of at least two thirds of the annual contribution assessment ceiling in the general pension insurance scheme
