context:
Life threatening emergency
Police:
110
Fire brigade:
112
Ambulance, emergency doctor:
112
Important!
Only for life-threatening emergencies and accidents
The emergency numbers of the mobile phones always work, even with a prepaid card without credit/money.
Important information for an emergency call:
Who is calling (your name)?
Where did the incident occur (address)?
What happened?
How many people are injured or sick?
What kind of diseases or injuries are present?
Wait for questions!
Stay calm.
Speak slowly and clearly so that you can be understood better.
Do not end the conversation.
The emergency call centre will end the call when it has all important information.
Also, always get other people around you involved if you need help.
Never put yourself in harm’s way.
If you are able, always provide first aid, or call someone who can.
Life-threatening emergencies are, for example:
severe shortness of breath
unconsciousness
heavily bleeding wounds
heart troubles
suspected stroke
symptoms of paralysis
complications during pregnancy
poisonings
Severe pain
Important!
Don't forget your ID card / proof of arrival when you go to the hospital!
If you are already registered with a health insurance company, bring your insurance card with you.
As an asylum seeker, you may also go to hospital without a treatment certificate in the event of an emergency.
At the hospital you have to show that you are an asylum seeker with your proof of arrival.

Toleration (§60a)
Duration: Limited in time
Status: Tolerated
Background: Negative asylum decision, obligation to leave the country
A "Duldung" is a temporary postponement of deportation and is not legal residence.
This document is only granted if deportation is impossible for legal, practical, humanitarian or personal reasons at the moment.
A work permit is generally required.
It is applied for at the Aliens' Registration Office of your place of residence.

questions.question: What safety measures should I follow to avoid coronavirus?
Where can I get tested for coronavirus in Germany?
How can I access healthcare services if I have symptoms?

context:
Information about Coronavirus
There are some general rules.
In addition, the federal states have the possibility to impose additional rules.
You may do this if an overload of the health system or critical infrastructure could occur.
Please inform yourself about possible additional rules in your federal state.
In general, the following recommendations and rules apply:
Rules for public life
Keep at least 1.5 to 2 metres away from other people in public.
Wearing a medical mask in public is generally recommended.
The number of contacts should be kept as constant and low as possible.
Clinics, old people's homes and care services
Masks are compulsory for access to hospitals and full and partial inpatient care facilities.
They must therefore wear an FFP2 mask, as the residents and patients in these facilities are particularly at risk.
Employees in outpatient care services must wear a mask during their work.
Medical practices
Patients and visitors may only enter doctors' surgeries, dentists' surgeries, dialysis facilities and other health care facilities wearing FFP2 masks.
Quarantine rules
In quarantine, a distinction is made between isolation for infected personsand quarantine for contact persons.
There is no longer an obligation to isolate infected persons.
Depending on the federal state, there are different measures for infected persons.
Please find out what applies in your federal state.

proper coughing and sneezing into a handkerchief or the crook of the arm
Keep your distance from people with coughs, colds or fever
Do not shake hands
Keep your hands away from your face

Should citizens experience symptoms of illness such as cough, fever or shortness of breath, they should:
contact the local health department by telephone.
You can find the contact details here: https://www.rki.de/mein-gesundheitsamt
contact your GP by telephone
The doctor will talk to you.
If corona virus is suspected, you will be further observed and treated.

questions.question: What rights does the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child guarantee for children?
What extra protections do children have under German law?
Who can I contact in the Rems-Murr District if I have concerns about a child's welfare?

context:
Children's rights
Children and young people have rights.
These rights are laid down in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.
It also applies in Germany to all children and young people under the age of 18.
In addition, there are many laws in Germany that protect the life, health and rights of children in a special way.
The protection of children always comes first.
This means, for example:
All children have the same rights.
No matter where they live, where they come from, what colour their skin is, what their parents do, what language they speak, what religion they have, whether they are a boy or a girl, what culture they live in, whether they have a disability, whether they are rich or poor.
Children have the right to a name, a birth certificate and a nationality, and to a family.
The state basically helps when children lack any of these things.
Children should be able to live with their parents unless this puts them in danger.
Parents may and must care for their children, protect and promote their health and well-being.
Children who have fled have the right to special protection and help.
Children must be protected so that they can grow up well.
Children must and may go to school.
There is compulsory schooling.
Parents must support their children in attending school.
School education is free in Germany.
Children are allowed to form their own opinions.
At the age of 14 at the latest, children are allowed to decide all by themselves whether they want to belong to a religion and which one.
Children should be able to develop well.
Parents are responsible for this.
If they need support, the state must help and, for example, provide food, clothing and a place to live.
Children whose parents are not married have the same rights as children who live with married parents.
This is not allowed in Germany, for example:
Children may not be neglected or abused.
Children may not be beaten or physically or emotionally abused in any way.
Children may not be used as labour until they are 13 years old.
When they are older, they may only engage in very limited work.
This must not affect their health and development.
Children must not be abducted or used as objects of trade.
It is forbidden to perform sexual acts on children.
Here you can find the rights of the child
in different languages.
Contact point
You have a problem?
If you have a conflict with your parents, the school or other people who do not respect your wishes and rights, the Child Protection Agency is there for you and will try to find a solution to the problem that suits you best.
For example, you can call the number against sorrow
or
Child Protection Association Rems-Murr District:
www.kinderschutzbund-schorndorf-waiblingen.de
info@kinderschutzbund-schorndorf.de

questions.question: How can I find a day care center or kindergarten for my child in Germany?
What documents do I need to enroll my child in a day care center or kindergarten?
Are there any German language requirements for my child to attend a day care center or kindergarten?

context:
Day care centre/kindergarten
What is a day care centre?
Before your child goes to school, they can attend a day care centre.
There are carers there who look after your child and support their development.
They are like teachers at school.
Day care centre is a collective term for various forms of childcare.
It is often just called a "day care centre ". If your child is 1-3 years old, the daycare centre is called a "crèche".
The crèche is often integrated into a daycare centre.
If your child is 3-6 years old (until they start school), the daycare centre is called a " kindergarten".
The kindergarten is also called "Kiga" or "Kindi".
From the age of 1, your child has the right to attend a day-care centre or day-care facility.
Attending a day care centre/kindergarten/crèche is voluntary and costs money.
Here you can find a multilingual video about daycare centres.
Why is a day care centre good for my child?
At the daycare centre, your child can play with other children, make friends and learn lots of new things.
They will also learn the German language here.
At the day care centre, children learn while they play.
The day care centre is a very important preparation for school.
In the penultimate year and shortly before your child starts school, there is a school enrolment examination.
Here you can find videos about the day care centre in different languages.
How can I enrol my child in the daycare centre?
Ask at the town hall in your municipality how you can enrol your child.
The social counselling/integration manager in the shared accommodation or the migration counselling and youth migration service can also help you to register your child at the kindergarten.
Unfortunately, there are not enough places in all day care centres.
It is therefore best to enrol your child several months to a year in advance and have it placed on the waiting list.
When is the daycare centre open?
There are different opening hours.
In day care centres, you can normally have your child looked after from the morning until late in the afternoon.
However, there are also kindergartens that are only open until midday (approx.
12:00 or 14:00).
You bring your child to the daycare centre in the morning and pick it up again at lunchtime or in the evening.
This depends on how long you have booked.
There are fixed times for this.
You have to stick to them.
This is very important for the children.
This allows the carers to support the children undisturbed.
Find out more directly from the daycare centre.
Child day care centre
The Child Day Care Centre is the point of contact for families and parents for all questions regarding child day care.

questions.question: Are there any restrictions on practicing religion in Germany?
How can I find a place of worship for my religion in Germany?
Can I wear religious clothing in public places in Germany?

context:
Religious freedom
Religion and faith are a private matter in Germany.
The state does not dictate to anyone whether and in which god he or she should believe.
State and religion are separate.
This means, for example:
All people are free to practise their religion and faith and to choose for themselves.
All people have the freedom not to be religious and to say so.
Those who do not believe in God may also say so publicly.
Members of different religions and beliefs may marry each other.
Marriage only counts as a legally valid marriage if it is concluded before the registry office.
Marriages concluded exclusively within the framework of a religion are not legally binding in Germany.
For example, it is not permitted in Germany:
To place religious rules or traditions above applicable laws, for example to be married to several women at the same time or to slaughter an animal without special permission.
Boys may only be circumcised if this does not endanger their well-being.
Many people in Germany today are committed to dialogue between religions.
The goal is the peaceful coexistence of religious people, people of faith and people who do not belong to any religion.
The state is obliged to maintain ideological neutrality.
As long as the practice of a religion does not endanger democracy or the separation of state and religion, it is protected.

context:
Integration Courses
The integration course consists of a language course and an orientation course.
In the language course you will learn German up to language level B1 in 600 teaching units.
In the subsequent orientation course, you will gain insights into the culture, politics and social customs in Germany.
There are also special forms of the integration course, which in some instances include more or fewer teaching units.
Who is the language course for?
Foreigners with a permanent residence permit.
You received your residence permit more than one year ago or have held it for more than 18 months (worker, family reunification, humanitarian reasons, long-term resident).
Late repatriates
Asylum seekers with a residence permit according to §55 par.
Foreigners with a tolerated stay in accordance with § 60 a para.
2 sentence 3 AufenthG.
Foreigners with a training permit pursuant to § 60c para.
1 or an employment permit pursuant to § 60d para.
1 AufenthG
Foreigners with a residence permit according to §24 or § 25 Para.
5 AufenthG.
Foreigners with a residence permit according to §25b (§ 104c AufenthG - "right of residence of opportunity")
EU citizens
German nationals who do not yet speak sufficient German or who are particularly in need of integration.
What types of language courses are available?
There are different forms of integration course.
Which ones are available can be found here.
General integration course
Literacy courses
Integration course for secondary learners
Youth integration course
Women's integration course
Parent integration course
Intensive course
Integration course for people with disabilities
What does the language course cost?
Integration courses are free of chargefor refugees and asylum seekers.
The course is also free of charge for other people in the target group who receive social benefits.
These persons need an application for this.
Further forms on costs and participation (e.g. application for travel allowance) are available here.
When and where do the language courses take place?
There are full-time courses and part-time courses.
In principle, the integration course is offered full-time.
If you are working, it is possible to attend the course in the afternoon or evening.
You can find local counselling centres and integration courses here.
You can find integration course providers here.
How can I register?
Here you can find the application forms.
The application for the integration course for asylum seekers, tolerated persons and foreigners with a residence permit according to §24 and § 25 Abs.
5 AufenthG can be found here.
Send the completed applications to the competent regional office of the BAMF.

You can find more information here.

questions.question: What kind of pregnancy support is available for refugees in Germany?

context:
Important information about pregnancy
First appointment with the gynaecologist
Pregnant women in Germany are under special protection and are entitled to counselling, medical care and support with new purchases for the child.
If you are pregnant, you must first visit your gynaecologist.
Have the check-ups carried out there.
You will then receive a maternity pass.
The maternity record is a document containing important information about your pregnancy, your health and that of your child.
Always take your maternity pass with you in case of emergencies.
Maternity protection for working pregnant women
Working pregnant women have special protection - known as maternity protection.
Maternity protection begins 6 weeks before the birth and ends 8 weeks afterwards.
This protection is regulated by law in Germany.
During this time, pregnant women are generally not allowed to work.
Your job remains the same and you can return to work at the end of your maternity leave.
In addition, pregnant women are not allowed to work more than 8.5 hours a day and are not allowed to carry out heavy physical labour.
Midwife
Midwives support women and their families from the beginning of pregnancy to the end of the breastfeeding period.
Midwives provide counselling during pregnancy, can help with the birth, introduce breastfeeding after the birth and also take care of the woman's physical and psychological recovery.
Any woman can call on the help of a midwife.
Most services are covered by health insurance.
Website of the Midwives' Association in German and English
Here you can find a midwife in the Rems-Murr district
Pregnancy counselling
Women and men can obtain free and anonymous advice on all questions, issues and changes relating to pregnancy and family planning.
Regardless of whether they need medical or legal information, for example.
The counselling service is also available for mothers and young families after the birth of a child.
Women and men with an unfulfilled desire to have children can also seek counselling.
Counselling centres Rems-Murr-Kreis:
Rem-Murr district office
schwanger@rems-murr-kreis.de
pro familia Waiblingen
waiblingen@profamilia.de
Financial support
If you have little or no income, you can apply for unemployment benefit II or assistance under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act (AsylbLG).
After the twelfth week of pregnancy, the
job centre or social welfare office will then pay expectant mothers additional needs and initial equipment for pregnancy and baby.
Child benefit
As a rule, all children in Germany are entitled to child benefit from birth until they reach the age of 18.
In individual cases, the entitlement may last longer.
Parental allowance
Many parents want to look after their child after the birth.
To do this, they do not work for a certain period of time.
Or they only work part-time.
Parental allowance is paid during this time.

You can find more information on the vocational training allowancehere.
Prospects for young refugees
Have you fled your home country and would like to start training in Germany?
Find out about special offers at the Employment Agency.
If you are younger than 25, the measure "Perspectives for Young Refugees (PerjuF)" will help you to find your way on the German training market.
Following this measure, you should be able to start a suitable apprenticeship.
During the first 2 weeks, your language skills will be tested.
It will also be determined how much support you need.
After that, you will find out whether you like working with wood or metal, for example, or whether you are suitable for the field of home economics.
As a rule, participation lasts 6 to 8 months.
The placement specialists at your employment agency or the integration specialists at the job centre will be happy to help you with any questions you may have.
Vocational guidance in working life (BBiE)
Whether you want to take on more responsibility in your job, update or expand your professional knowledge or reorient yourself professionally: The Employment Agency's Vocational Guidance in Working Life (BBiE) supports you in every phase of your professional life.
We will advise you comprehensively and individually every step of the way - from initial orientation to the selection of a suitable, subsidised continuing education programme to the search for a new job.

questions.question: Which legal rights do I have as a refugee in Germany?
How can I find legal advice in Germany?
What is the process for seeking asylum in Germany?

context:
Rule of law
Germany is a democratic constitutional state.
The Basic Law guarantees human dignity, freedom and justice.
There are laws to ensure that human rights are respected.
Political decisions are made by representatives of the people.
The people's representatives are elected by the Germans in free elections.
The laws apply equally to all people in Germany.
The state must abide by the laws.
All people living in Germany must also abide by German laws.
That means, for example:
If people think that other people or the public administration are doing them wrong, they can turn to a court.
These courts are independent.
This means: the government is not allowed to tell the courts how to decide.
State courts decide whether someone is punished.
Punishments are, for example, fines, community service or prison.
There is no death penalty in Germany.
The police have the task of ensuring that all people can live in freedom and safety.
The practice of religion must not violate laws.
The laws always take precedence over religion.
This is not allowed in Germany, for example:
To incite hatred or violence.
To fight the democratic system and its values.
These offences can lead to a prison sentence.
After serving the sentence, non-German nationals can lose their right to stay under certain conditions and be deported.

context:
Entry from Ukraine and residence in Germany
Current information and entry requirements:
Federal Foreign Office
Federal Office for Migration and Refugees.
Further information specifically for the Rems-Murr district can be found here.
Can I enter Germany legally and stay there legally?
Foreigners normally require a residence permit - such as a visa or a residence authorisation - to enter and legally stay in Germany.
Due to the special situation in Ukraine, an exception to this rule has been made: War refugees from Ukraine are temporarily exempt from the requirement of a residence permit in Germany.
What happens after entry?
Where can I register in Germany and where do I get accommodation and meals?
The procedure is divided into four consecutive steps:
First registration
Allocation to a place of residence (if you receive social benefits)
Registration of the residential address at the destination
Application for a residence permit.
Further information can be found here.
Can I work in Germany with a residence permit for temporary protection?
Yes, this is possible.
However, gainful employment must first be authorised by the immigration
authority .
When issuing the residence permit, the immigration authority will already enter in the residence title that gainful employment is permitted.
This means that no further work permit from another authority is required.
Should Ukrainian nationals apply for asylum?
No, this is not necessary.
The necessary protection is granted in a different, faster procedure.
Ukrainian nationals are therefore advised not to apply for asylum.
However, the right to apply for asylum at a later date remains unaffected.
Information portal of the German government
The Federal Ministry offers a digital information portal in German, English, Russian and Ukrainian.
Here you will find all official information about residence and life in Germany.
Germany4Ukraine
Embassy of Ukraine in Berlin

Vocational preparation and training preparation
VABO - Pre-qualification for a job without German language skills
At the schools, young people initially receive intensive language support in so-called VABO classes (pre-qualification year for work/occupation with a focus on acquiring German language skills at vocational schools) and are prepared for the transition to training and work.
Age: younger than 19
Duration: 1 year full-time (repetition possible)
Prerequisite: little or no knowledge of German
Focus: Acquisition of the German language
Certificate: A2 or B1
Connection: Change to AVdual, start a helper training programme, employment agency measures, a Voluntary Social Year (FSJ), Voluntary Ecological Year (FÖJ) or looking for a job.
From now on, pupils should use the following link to register for the VABO programme:
VABO registration
AVdual - dual training preparation programme
Age: possible from 15/16 years - up to approx.
25
Duration: 1 year full-time (repetition possible)
Prerequisite: at least language level A2
Focus: Vocational orientation, many internships
Certificate: Secondary school leaving certificate
Follow-up: Start an apprenticeship, 1-year vocational school or 2-year vocational school, employment agency measures, FSJ, FÖJ or looking for a job
You can find more detailed information about AVdual here.
BEJ - vocational entry year
Age: possible from 15/16 years
Duration: 1 year full-time
Prerequisite: Secondary school leaving certificate and/or still required to attend vocational school
Focus: Vocational preparation and improvement of training skills
Certificate: none or improvement of the lower secondary school leaving certificate

questions.question: Where can I buy groceries in Germany?
How can I find local shops and malls?
What are the popular German supermarket chains?

context:
Shopping Facilities
In Germany, shops are generally open from Monday to Saturday.
They are usually closed on Sundays and public holidays.
The opening hours of the shops may vary.
You can find out about this on the Internet or at the entrance to the respective shops.
Restaurants, cafés and leisure facilities (for example swimming pools, museums, cinemas) are also open on Sundays and public holidays.
Here you can shop:
Discount shops
In discount shops you can mainly buy cheaper food.
The range of goods is relatively limited and is presented in a simple way.
There are discount shops in almost every town.
Supermarkets
In supermarkets you can mainly buy somewhat more expensive food.
Here you will also find many branded products.
Greater importance is attached to the presentation of the goods than is the case with discount shops.
Weekly markets
At the weekly markets you can buy primarily regional food (e.g. fruit, vegetables, eggs, bread).
The weekly markets are only held on certain days of the week and usually in the morning.
But there is not a weekly market in every town.
Specialist shops
Specialist shops are shops where you can buy mainly goods of a certain category.
These are, for example, bakeries, butchers, sports shops, shoe shops.
Retail shops with foreign products
There are shops, especially in larger cities, where you can buy foreign products.
There are, for example, Turkish, Russian or Asian food shops.
Drugstores
Drugstores are specialist shops with an extensive assortment.
Here you can buy mainly hygiene products (e.g. shampoo, cleaning agents) or cleaning products (e.g. washing powder, washing-up liquid).

context:
Child day care
What is childminding?
Childminding is the care of children by childminders.
If required, children from 0 to 14 years of age can be looked after by a childminder.
The children are looked after in the childminder's home, in their own home or in other rooms.
The care takes place in small groups.
Day care is a family-like form of childcare.
It is mainly used by children under the age of 3. Your child can receive individualised support here.
The childcare hours are agreed flexibly between parents and childminders.
It can also supplement childcare in a day care centre.
From the age of 1, your child has the right to attend a daycare centre or childminder.
Attending a day care centre/kindergarten/crèche/day care is voluntary and costs money.
How do I find a place with a childminder?

About Integreat
Integreat is a guide that supports you in your everyday life.
You will findimportant addresses, contact persons as well as tips and tricks that can help you find yourway around.
This guide has several chapters.
Each chapter deals with a different topic.
Among other things, you will find information on doctors, schools, German courses or other institutions.
There is also a chapter with ideas on what you can do in your free time.
The information and leisure activities change.
Your municipality updates them regularly.
That's why it's very good if you check your mobile app often.
You will always be informed about current activities and events.
You can rely on the information in Integreat.
Download Integreat from your app store.
You can also use this app offline if you don't have internet access.
When you are back online, the app will update itself.
Sharing information
You can download and share important information, for example, as a PDF in the web app.
In the mobile app, you can share interesting content directly, for example via WhatsApp, Facebook or email.
Latest news
With the Integreat smartphone app you can also receive push notifications.
You can agree to receive them in the app's settings.
Push notifications will send you important or last-minute information.
Feedback
You can contribute to the development of the Integreat app in your municipality.
You can give feedback using the smiley icons.
This feedback ends up with the people who create the content.
You can praise or criticise.
If you have ideas or criticism, write down as many details as possible.
Read aloud function
The content of the Integreat app can also be read aloud.
To do this, the read aloud function must be switched on in the settings of the smartphone.
This works in all languages.
We very much hope that we can simplify your life in Germany with this app.

context:
Save electricity and energy
Normally the new tenants are automatically registered by the landlord with the electricity supplier.
You can choose the electricity provider yourself.
After a notice period of approximately 2 weeks, you can change your electricity provider.
The best way to find an overview of providers and price comparisons is via the independent energy consumer portal.
www.energieverbraucherportal.de
Saving energy = saving money
Make sure you ventilate regularly (open the window fully for 5 minutes at least 3 times a day) and heat properly.
In this way, you prevent mould from developing and save energy and thus money.
Detailed information and helpful tips are available from the consumer advice centre in various languages.
Saving energy
Power-saving check
People on low incomes or social benefits learn how to save energy in their homes during the electricity savings check.
In this way, they save money in the long term and protect the climate.
The consultations are free of charge.
The electricity savings checks can be carried out as a consultation and in the home and consist of two appointments.
Households are given tips on energy-saving behaviour and receive a free starter pack containing energy-saving light bulbs, sockets with off-switches, energy-saving showers and more.

questions.question: How can I get my degree recognized in Germany?
What documents are needed for degree recognition?

context:
Foreign degree
You can have it checked whether your degree is recognised in Germany.
Note that there is a difference in recognition between regulated and non-regulated professions.
Regulated professions
You may only work in regulated professions if a certain qualification is available.
These are, for example
Medical professions
Legal professions
The teaching profession at state schools
Professions in the public sector
This means that in these professions you may only work with a state recognition of the professional qualification (for example, vocational qualification or university degree).
In the Anerkennungs-Finder you can search for the competent recognition body for regulated professions.
You will also receive information on how to proceed.
Non-regulated professions
In non-regulated professions, you may work without the state recognition of professional qualifications.
However, it is recommended to apply for a certificate evaluation.
The Central Office for Foreign Education (ZAB) in Bonn is responsible for the assessment of certificates for non-regulated academic professions.
Further information
Here you will find further information on the recognition of your university degree from abroad.

questions.question: What health insurance options are available for newcomers?
How can I apply for public health insurance as a refugee?
What services does a typical health insurance plan cover in Germany?

context:
Health insurance and health insurance
In Germany, insurance is compulsory.
This means you have to be a member of a health insurance fund to see a doctor.
As soon as you have a residence title , you must register with a regular health insurance fund.
You can choose and change the health insurance company yourself.
You will receive an insurance card from the health insurance company and are thus entitled to the same services as all residents in Germany.
Always take the insurance card with you to your appointments with the doctors.
Here you will find an overview of the health insurance funds in Germany.
The basic medical care provided by the health insurance company includes:
Services to prevent and alleviate diseases
Services during pregnancy
Services for the detection of diseases
Services for the treatment of diseases
Costs
If you go to see a doctor, please present your health insurance card.
With this, most examinations are free of charge foryou.
You must pay for certain preventive medical checkups yourself.
For therapies (for example, physiotherapy) and aids (for example, bandages) you have to pay a contribution yourself.
People who have limited funds can be exempted from this.
Please ask your health insurance company about this.
The costs of dental treatment are paid by the health insurance.
If a tooth needs to be renewed or replaced, you will have to pay for part of it yourself.
The costs of hospital treatment are also paid by the health insurance company.
However, you have to pay a daily hospital allowance of € 10for each dayspent in hospital.
People who have limited funds can be exempted from this.

Office for Social Affairs and Participation
The Office for Social Affairs and Participation takes care of people who cannot work and therefore do not earn any money.
These can be sick or old people , but also, for example, single women or men.
These people can apply for so-called social assistance .
The office checks whether the applicants cannot finance their lives with their own means.
If this is not possible, the office pays aid to ensure people's subsistence level.
It covers the costs of living, rent and other expenses.
The Social Welfare Office is the point of contact for a wide range of financial assistance.
But you can also find advice and help on various social situations here.

context:
Citizen's income
You are entitled to citizen's allowance from the Job Centre if you meet certain conditions.
You can receive citizen's allowance if you are able to work and entitled to benefits and therefore fulfil at least the following conditions:
You are at least 15 years old and you have not yet reached the age limit for your pension.
You live in Germany and have your centre of life here.
You can work at least 3 hours a day.
You or members of your benefit community are in need of assistance.
In need of assistance means that the income of your benefit community is below the minimum subsistence level and you are unable to cover your living expenses from your own resources.
Able to work means that no illness or disability prevents you from taking up work.
Anyone who is not able to work can also receive citizen's allowance if they live in a community of need with a person who is able to work and entitled to benefits.
You will receive
a standard rate
Housing and heating costs
Health insurance and nursing care insurance
Initial equipment for housing and clothing
Integration into the labour market.
Register with the job centre.
You can apply for citizen's allowance onlinehere.
Please note: Benefits under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act are subordinate to all other financial support and your own income.

questions.question: What documents are needed for school registration?
How can I enroll my child in a German school?
Are there any language requirements for school admission?

context:
How do I register my child in a school?
Are you new to Germany?
Your child may go to a school.
After 6 months in Germany at the latest, you must register your child at a school.
School attendance is compulsory.
Ask at the city hall which school your child can go to.
There are special classes to learn German.
You can find more information here.
Have you been in Germany for a while?
Your child already attends a day care centre or a primary school?
There are specific days for registration.
You will need the following documents:
Your identity card, birth certificate or proof of arrival
Registration certificate
all documents concerning your child (identity card/passport, birth certificate, school reports, medical certificates, ...)
Please bring your child to school for registration.
School enrolment dates and registration dates at primary schools in Baden-Württemberg:
Baden-Württemberg reference date: End of June.
(Your child must be 6 years old by that day)
School enrolment: Beginning of March until end of April
School enrollment: September
You can find information about school enrolment (primary school) here.
Enrolment and registration dates for other schools (secondary schools) in Baden-Württemberg:
Registration dates take place in March.
Check with the school several weeks or months before this date.
Note: For vocational schools, there are other times when you can register.
Check with the school early.
You do not know which school your child should go to?
Ask your socialcounselling/integration manager, youth migration counselling or migration counselling.
You can also obtain information at the “Rathaus” (town hall) or directly at the schools in your place of residence.

questions.question: How can I find a pharmacy in Germany?
What is the process to get prescribed medication in Germany?
How can I get over-the-counter medication in Germany?

context:
Pharmacy and medicines
Pharmacies (Apotheken)
In Germany, you canonly get medicinesin pharmacies.
In other shops or in the doctor's office you will not get any medicine.
Every pharmacy can be recognised from the outside by the red A.
Pharmacies are openfrom Monday to Saturday.
The opening times vary according to each chemist.
If you urgently need medication outside normal opening hours, you will find a sign at every chemist with the name and address of the chemist which is open for emergencies.
Search for pharmacies near you
Search pharmacy emergency service
Medication
There are prescription and over-the-counter drugs.
You can only getprescription medicines if a doctor issues a prescription.
Prescription drugs are, for example, drugs for high blood pressure or diabetes and all antibiotics for bacterial infections.
You can getover-the-counter medicines at the pharmacy without a prescription.
So you don't have to see a doctor beforehand.
Over-the-counter drugs are, for example, drugs for colds and many drugs for pain.
Recipe colours:
Pink: This is the colour of the prescription sheet for people with statutory health insurance.
Such a prescription is valid for 28 days.
Green: On these prescription sheets, doctors recommend over-the-counter medicines.
Such a prescription is valid indefinitely.
Blue: This is the prescription sheet for privately insured persons.
Such a prescription is valid for three months in most cases.
Yellow: Narcotics are prescribed on these prescriptions, for example strong painkillers.
Such a prescription is valid for 7 days.
Cost of medicines
Statutory health insurance: Drugs (pink prescription) are partly paid by health insurance companies.
You have to pay a co-payment of at least 5 € yourself.
You do not have to pay this for children up to 18 years of age.
Medicines that do not require a prescription (for example, cough syrup) must be paid for by yourself (green or blue prescription).
Health care for asylum seekers: Even with a prescription, not all medicines are free.
Therefore, check with your doctor.

questions.question: What are the signs of labor exploitation to look out for?
How can I report a case of labor exploitation in Germany?
What resources are available to help victims of labor exploitation?

context:
Work exploitation
Labour exploitation is when labour is exploited under unfair conditions or without the consent of the people concerned.
Slavery and forced labour are prohibited in Germany!
Human trafficking for the purpose of labour exploitation or forced sex work is prohibited in Germany!
Other forms of work exploitation are also criminal offences:
Refusing to pay wages despite work being carried out
Longer periods of work than was contractually agreed for the same salary (circumventing the minimum wage)
Refusing to pay additional wages that are due to the worker such as payment in the event of illness or paid holiday
For more information, please contact the following counselling centre.

questions.question: What are the rights and responsibilities of asylum seekers in Germany?
How can I apply for an Asylum Seekers' Permit in Germany?
What is the duration of an Asylum Seekers' Permit in Germany?

context:
Temporary Residence Permit (Aufenthaltsgestattung)
Duration: Limited in time
Status: Asylum seekers
Background: Issued for the purpose of conducting an asylum procedure until the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) reaches a decision.
This is NOT a residence permit!
The asylum seeker's identity document contains conditions relating to employment, housing situation and territorial restrictions.
The Agentur für Arbeit (Federal Employment Agency) is responsible for the placement in work.
If a work permit is necessary, it can be obtained from the “Ausländerbehörde” (Immigration Office) of your place of residence.
To do this, you must fill in applications with the help of your employer.
Your social worker will help you fill it out.
These are the applications:
Job description
Declaration on the employment relationship
If you do not work, you will receive benefits according to the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act.

questions.question: How much do I need to pay for childcare in Germany?
Are there any government subsidies for childcare costs?
What documents do I need to provide for childcare fee assistance?

context:
Childcare costs
Attending a day care centre or day care facility costs money.
You can find out the costs directly from the town hall or the specific facility.
Families with several children often receive discounts.
If you do not have a job and receive benefits from the “Landratsamt” (District Office – asylum seeker benefits), the Job Centre or the “Agentur für Arbeit” (Federal Employment Agency), you can get assistance with the costs.
To do this, you must submit an application to the YouthWelfareOffice at the District Office(Wirtschaftliche Jugendhilfe).
Click here for the applications and contact details
Often, the day care centre also offers a lunch together.
There are also vouchers for this.
You must submit an application for Education and participation, or BuT for shortat the district administration office
Here you can access the applications of BuT

questions.question: What types of schools offer education in Germany?
How can I enroll in a German university as a foreigner?
What German language proficiency level is required for studying in Germany?

context:
General information about studying
Different types of universities
There are different types of universitiesin Germany:
Universitäten = universities (more academically focused)
Pädagogische Hochschulen = Teacher training colleges (for social subjects)
Hochschulen für Angewandte Wissenschaften = Universities of Applied Sciences (practice-oriented)
Dual universities: very practice-oriented, you work and study
Art schools, film schools and music colleges: for artistic subjects
There are public and private universities.
Private universities are not necessarily better than public ones – however, students usually have to pay high tuition fees at private universities.
Study programmes
There are also many different courses of study.
An overview is available here.
Further information
You can find detailed information about studying in Germany here:
Arbeitsagentur

questions.question: What documents are needed for a residence permit application?
How long does it take to get a residence permit in Germany?
Can I work while my residence permit application is being processed?

context:
Residence permit
The residence permit can be granted for various reasons, for example for humanitarian or family reasons or after a positive asylum decision.
Duration: Limited in time
The residence permit (Aufenthaltserlaubnis) grants temporary residence.
It is always earmarked.
It forms the basis for legal residence and opens up the possibility of a subsequent permanent right of residence (settlement permit).
Some residence permits allow unrestricted access to the labour market without a work permit from the “Bundesagentur für Arbeit” (Federal Employment Agency).
Other residence permits require the approval of the Federal Agency.
Every residence permit states the extent to which work is permitted.
Here you will find the applications to apply for or extend a residence permit:
Application for a residence permit / EU Blue Card (PDF file)
Application for a residence permit for a child under 16 (PDF file)
Application for extension of a residence permit / EU Blue Card (PDF file)
Application for extension of a residence permit for a child under 16 (PDF file)

questions.question: How can I get help if I have a workplace accident in Germany?
Who should I contact if I am injured at work in Germany?
What are my rights if I am involved in a workplace accident in Germany?

context:
Accident at work
If you have an accident during working hours or on the way to or from work, it is an occupational accident.
In this case, you are insured through the company by an accident insurance.
If you go to the doctor or hospital you must tell them that it’s an accident at work.
The treatment is then not paid for by the health insurance company, but by the employer's accident insurance.
You can find out the name of the accident insurance company from your employer.
If you have an accident at work and
are unfit for work for more than one day or
require medical treatment for longer or
become ill again at a later date
you must consult a so-called transit doctor.
You can find transit doctors on the website of the German Social Accident Insurance (Deutsche Gesetzliche Unfallversicherung)

questions.question: How can I volunteer in Germany to help with my integration?
What advantages do I gain from volunteering as a refugee in Germany?
Which organizations in Germany offer volunteering opportunities for newcomers?

context:
Volunteer
Volunteering means that people work for an issue voluntarily and without money in addition to their work.
You can volunteer in these areas:
Refugee assistance
Nature conservation
voluntary fire brigade
Activities in the religious field
Music clubs and sports clubs
Often these people are organised in associations.
Volunteering brings together people with similar interests.
Volunteering is therefore important for everyone.
You can become a volunteer, too, and get to know people in your area.
If you are interested in volunteering, you can contact the municipality where you live.

questions.question: What information is included in a German salary statement?
How can I understand my German salary statement?
Who can I contact for help with my German salary statement?

context:
Salary statement
If you are employed as a worker, you will receive a pay slip or wage slipafter the first month of work.
Some employers will still issue you with a monthly statement after that, others only if something is different in that month than usual (for example, Christmas bonus, increase in insurance contributions).
These details must be shown in the salary statement or payslip:
Name and address of employer
Name, address, date of birth of the employee
Employer's insurance number
Date of beginning the employment
Tax class and tax identification number (Steueridentifikationsnummer)
Accounting period
Gross salary (salary without deductions – gross tax amount and gross social security amount)
Type and amount of surcharges or bonuses
Type and amount of deductionsNet amount (after all deductions)
The net amount is usually the amount you receive.
Exception: If there were advance payments, or loans from the company or salary seizure (if you have debts), further amounts will be removed from the net amount.

questions.question: How can I get my foreign qualifications recognized in Germany?
What documents do I need for the recognition process?
Where can I find help for the recognition of my qualifications?

context:
Recognition of foreign qualifications
Qualifications play an important role in Germany for school, studies or work.
With qualification certificates you can prove what you have already learned and achieved.
Qualifications are an important prerequisite for a place at a school, university or job.
This means that if you have already acquired qualifications at school, in an apprenticeship or in a course of study abroad, you can have these recognised.
There will be a review to check what you are qualified to do in Germany based on your qualifications.
Your qualifications are “transposed” so to speak.

questions.question: What documents do I need for registering as an EU migrant?
Where can I go to register as an EU migrant in Germany?
What is the process for late repatriation in Germany?

context:
EU migrants and ethnic repatriates
EU migrants
If you are a citizen of a member state of the EU, you can in principle enter Germany legally and live and work there (Freedom of Movement Act).
You must then register at the Residents' Registration Office responsible for you (locally in the municipality/city hall).
You will need a valid identity card or a valid passport from your country of origin.
Note: If you do not work, you may not be entitled to social benefits in Germany for the first 5 years of your stay.
Here it is important that you make an appointment for counselling with the Job Centre .
You can find more information here.
A brochure of the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) in German, English and other languages can be found here.
Late repatriates
After you have received your entry form in your country of origin, you may enter Germany.
There, you will be assigned to a district by the Federal Office of Administration in Friedland (for example, the Rems-Murr district) and accommodated by it if you cannot find a private flat.
You can find more information here.
You can find a Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) brochure in German and Russian here.

questions.question: Where can I get help for Female Genital Mutilation in Germany?
What laws protect against Female Genital Mutilation in Germany?
How can I report a case of Female Genital Mutilation in Germany?

context:
Counselling regarding female genital mutilation
In Germany, female genital mutilation (FGM)is prohibited.
Parents are also not allowed to leave the country to have their daughter circumcised abroad.
This is also punishable under German law.
Girls and young women can apply for asylum if they are in danger of being cut.
Many girls die during genital mutilation or from its consequences.
There are also many dangerous after-effects of mutilation.
If you have been affected or threatened by genital mutilation, contact the help hotline at
The help hotline staff are there for you day and night and in different languages.
In Germany, it is possible to get clitoral reconstruction surgery.
This operation can be performed by plastic surgeons.
Ask a gynaecologist (women’s doctor) for advice.
You can find more information in the official protection letter of the Federal Government in several languages.
Contact details
In Göppingen there is a central contact point for women with FGM.
News - FGM/C Central Contact Point Baden-Württemberg (fgmc-bw.de)

questions.question: What assistance does Voluntary Return Counselling provide?
How can I contact Voluntary Return Counselling in Germany?
What does "voluntary return" mean in this context?

context:
Return counselling
Do you want to return to your home country before the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) has decided on your asylum application?
You don't know how to get your passport back or you need financial help for your return journey?
The return counselling service will advise you on options for voluntary departure to your home country.
The counselling is open-ended.
This means that you decide for yourself after the counselling whether you want to leave voluntarily or not.
The main target group are people in the Rems-Murr district who are considering voluntary departure and return to their home country.
This applies in particular to
Foreign nationals without a right of residence (e.g. tolerated persons)
Asylum seekers in the ongoing procedure
Foreign nationals with only a temporary right of residence for humanitarian reasons
Foreign nationals who have a permanent right of residence
Contact
Frank Polachowski
Return counselling
f.polachowski@rems-murr-kreis.de

questions.question: "What types of full-time vocational training are available for newcomers in Germany?"
"How can I apply for full-time vocational training in Germany?"
"What qualifications do I need for full-time vocational training in Germany?"

context:
Full-time school-based training
In Germany, however, not only is there the option for dual training, but there is also full-time school-based training at a vocational school (Berufsfachschule).
This type of training provides a completed vocational training in theory and practice outside of the dual training system (without an apprenticeship at a company).
It usually lasts two to three and a half years.
The course is full-time and includes general subjects in addition to the professional subjects.
Vocational schools vary greatly in terms of their training courses, admission requirements, duration of training and further education opportunities.
Please enquire at the respective school in each individual case.

questions.question: What does German language level A1, A2, B1, B2, C1, C2 mean?
How can I test my German language proficiency level?
Where can I find language courses for a specific proficiency level?

context:
What are the language levels?
The levels
The basic levels are:
A: Elementary language skills
B: Independent language skills
C: Competent language skills
These three levels are further subdivided into two levels each.
A detailed description of the knowledge behind each level can be found in the following table:
Level:
A1
Can understand and use familiar everyday expressions and very basic phrases.
This includes, for example, the question and answer regarding the place of residence.
A2
The person is able to understand sentences and frequently used expressions related to the essential aspects of everyday life.
This includes, for example, the description of your own job or training.
B1
The person understands the most important contents when using a clear standard language when dealing with familiar matters at work, school or leisure.
This enables the person to express themselves in a simple and coherent way about familiar topics and personal areas of interest, for example, about what goals the person is pursuing.
B2
The person is able to understand the most important contents of complex texts and also understands technical discussions in his/her own special field, for example, in vocational school.
The person is able to communicate so spontaneously and fluently that a conversation with native speakers is easily possible without much effort on either side.
C1
The person understands a wide range of demanding, longer texts and can also perceive implicit meanings that are not expressed openly.
In addition, the person is able to speak spontaneously and fluently - for example at work - and to express himself or herself on complex topics.
C2
The person can understand practically everything he or she reads and hears without effort.
They can express themselves spontaneously, very fluently and precisely.
Further information at: europaeischer-referenzrahmen.de

questions.question: What types of vocational training are available for refugees in Germany?
How can I enroll in a vocational training program as a refugee in Germany?
What documents are needed for starting vocational training in Germany?

context:
Dual training
A special feature in Germany is the dual training system.
Dual training takes place about one third of the time in vocational school and about two thirds in a training company.
In this way you get to know theory and practice at the same time and earn money in a company during your training.
If you want to apply for an apprenticeship, German language skills are very important (at least B1).
This is because German is spoken in companies and vocational schools and technical colleges.
The tests will also be held in German.
In a short filmby the network Unternehmen integrieren Flüchtlinge (Companies Integrate Refugees), vocational training is presented in different languages.

questions.question: What types of German classes can I take to become self-reliant?
Where can I find and sign up for German courses in Germany?
What abilities and skills will I have upon achieving a B2 language level?

context:
Learn German independently
You can, of course, also learn German independently – without attending a course or in addition to a course.
Your Support Network can support your learning.
Librariesare an important place to learn German independently.
Learning in the library and using the WLAN and internet PCs are free of charge.
Online services
There are also free offers on the internet to learn German:
The Goethe Institut has a free online offer with exercises for German at work.
The exercises are specially adapted to certain job categories.
The radio station Deutsche Welle offers online language exercises that work with video contributions and series.
They are adapted for language levels A1 to C and offer an entertaining complement to other German courses.
VHS- Lernportal
For immigrants who want to learn the German language quickly and without bureaucratic hurdles, the German Adult Education Association (DVV) has now put a free learning offer online.
The learning portal is available at vhs-lernportal.de and can be run on all common end devices.

questions.question: What kind of social support is available in shared accommodations?
How can I access social support services in my shared accommodation?
Who can I contact for help with social integration in my shared accommodation?

context:
Social support in shared accommodation
Caritas and the Kreisdiakonieverband are responsible for social care in the shared accommodation facilities in the Rems-Murr district.
The main tasks are counselling, mediation and support in all matters of daily life, family, employment and the organisation of community life in accommodation and neighbourhood.
The tasks also include accompanying volunteers.
The contact details are posted in the respective accommodation.
For general questions regarding social care in the Rems-Murr district, you can also contact the following office:
Social management of refugee social care in the Rems-Murr district
sozialmanagement@rems-murr-kreis.de

questions.question: What types of follow-up accommodations are available in Germany?
How can I apply for follow-up accommodation as a refugee?
Who can help me find a suitable follow-up accommodation?

context:
Subsequent accommodation (Anschlussunterbringung)
You will be placed in follow-up accommodation if you have lived in a shared accommodation for more than two years or your asylum procedure has been legally concludedor you have received a residence permit.
In the case of follow-up accommodation, you will move out of the shared accommodation and into accommodation in a city or municipality of the Rems-Murr district.
from this point on, you can also move into your own flat .
If you are no longer in temporary accommodation but in follow-up accommodation or already live in your own flat in the district, the integration managementwill help you.
The integration management can help you with questions about kindergarten, school, work, training, language courses, residence, family and with problems.
You can find the contacts for this under cities and municipalities.

Where can I purchase public transport tickets in Germany?

Bus and train
To get to your destination in the Rems-Murr district, public transport is available.
That's bus and train.

questions.question: What is an "Advance Maintenance Payment" in Germany?

context:
Advance Maintenance Payments
You live alone with your child and the other parent (mother or father) pays irregularly or no maintenance (money) for your child?
In this case, you may be able to receive advance maintenance payments (financial support) for your child.
However, the other parent (mother or father) may haveto pay the money back.
You must apply for the advance maintenance payments yourself.
You make the application at the Unterhaltsvorschusskasse at the Landratsamt.
Here you will find further information on the subject of advance maintenance payments and the application form.

How much does school cost?
General and administrative expenses
Attendance at a state school is free of charge.
Ticket

With this season ticket, pupils can travel inexpensively by bus and train in the entire VVS area and even in the whole of Baden-Württemberg.

School trips, school materials, lunch

The courses offered by adult education centres consist of courses of various durations, usually between 1 and 15 weeks.

questions.question: Who can I contact for urgent help in Germany?
What are the emergency hotline numbers in Germany?
How can I get immediate medical assistance in Germany?

context:
What do I do in an emergency?
If you need help very quickly in an emergency situation, the emergency numbers will help you.
You can also call the telephone pastoral care service (“Telefon-Seelsorge”).
There you will be advised directly on the phone:
The call is free and you can always call.
You do not have to say your name and you will not be asked for it.
For children and young people, there is the number for those struggling with worries or concerns:
What can you do in the event of an acute mental health crisis?
Anyone can have a mental health crisis - no matter how old they are, how they live or where they come from.
You can have a crisis because something very bad has happened to you (for example, someone has died, you are in great danger war...). You can also have a crisis if you have been experiencing bad things for a long time or are seriously mentally ill (for example, have depression or anxiety disorders).
In an emergency, call 112.
If you have a crisis or think you want to die, you can also always go to a hospital - day and night and at weekends.
For the Rems-Murr district
Centre for Mental Health Winnenden
Winnenden Castle Hospital
info@zfp-winnenden.de
The following offers are available here:
Outpatient offers
Partial inpatient offers
Inpatient offers
You can find more information here.

context:
Contact Point Women and Work
The contact point "Frau und Beruf" (Women and Work) actively advocates for women.
They open doors and show how companies and women can implement the topic of compatibility.
They support women in implementing their professional plans.
They show women entrepreneurs the way to self-employment.
Women returning to work are shown ways of gaining qualifications and entering the labour market.
In the case of reorientation and change, they work out new perspectives together with you.
Make a free appointment for counselling

questions.question: Which job counseling services are available for newcomers in Germany?
How can I get in touch with job counseling services in Germany?
What does a job counselor typically help with in Germany?

context:
Employment Agency
The Employment Agency (SGB III) is responsible for asylum seekers and persons with tolerated status who receive benefits under the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act.
Job placement
Are you looking for a job or do you want to do further vocational training?
You can discuss these and many other questions with the job centre.
The employment counsellors at all locations in the agency district will be happy to help and advise you.
Further information
Job placement
Advice on taking up employment
Advice on further vocational training
Information on looking for work and finding a job
Many of your questions can be clarified in a personal meeting, arrange your counselling appointment, also by telephone.
Careers counselling
Careers counselling supports you in your choice of studies and career, during your training and at the beginning of your working life.
You can clarify important questions about your professional future in a personal counselling session.
Counselling is available for
School pupils
trainees
students and
university graduates.
In addition, anyone who is seeking vocational training for the first time or wants to reorient themselves professionally.
Careers counselling can help you, for example
find a suitable profession or degree programme
clarify questions about the content of an apprenticeship or degree programme
find a training place and apply for it
develop alternatives if your dream job doesn't work out
utilise funding opportunities
obtain information on the training market or labour market.
You can find out what else careers counselling can do for you in the information sheet on careers counselling services for teenagers and young adults.

questions.question: What documents are needed for identity verification?
How long does the identity clarification process take?
Who can I contact for help with the identity clarification process?

context:
Identity clarification
You entered Germany without a passport?
The authorities need to know who you are:
what is your name
when you were born and
which country you are from
This is called identity.
To do this, you need evidence.
The best proof is the passport from your home country.
If you do not have a passport, you can alternatively present other identity documents as proof (example: Identity card, citizenship card, birth certificate, driving licence).
In Germany, all foreigners are subject to a passport obligation.
Exceptions to the passport requirement may be permitted in justified individual cases.
If you do not have a passport, you are required to obtain one.
Your cooperation in obtaining a passport is vital.
This is because your cooperation in obtaining a passport or in clarifying your identity can be taken into account by the Aliens Department when it comes to decisions under aliens law.
Cooperation obligations
General duties to cooperate "The foreigner is personally obliged to cooperate in clarifying the facts of the case."
(§ 15 Asylum Act):
You are committed to
provide required information orally and, upon request, also in writing
Present and surrender your passport or passport replacement to the authorities
to present and leave all necessary documents with the authority (example: visas issued by other states, residence permits, airline tickets, driving licences, birth certificates, military passports, marriage certificates, testimonials)
if you do not have a valid passport or passport replacement, to cooperate in obtaining an identity document
to present, hand over and temporarily surrender your passport, passport substitute or the substitute identity document at the request of the authority
Important notes:
Hand over all identity documents to the Aliens' Registration Office or the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees.
Have the authority make a copy of your documents and confirm the submission in writing.
If you do not have papers, contact parents or siblings in your home country and ask them to get the documents.
Alternatively, you can hire a lawyer or other persons in your home country to obtain identity documents.
Write down all the steps of your involvement in the identity clarification process and collect evidence.
While the asylum procedure is still ongoing, you cannot be required by the German authorities to appear at your embassy.
Passport obligation in the asylum procedure
During the asylum procedure, the Aliens' Registration Office cannot require passports to be obtained, but passport obligations still apply, for example they are fulfilled by the possession of a substitute identity card.

questions.question: What changes does Germany's new prostitution law bring?
Who does the new law affect in Germany?
How does the new law aim to protect people in prostitution?

context:
Counselling for people in prostitution
The Prostitute Protection Act (ProstSchG;
This law is intended to better regulate the protection of prostitutes.
This law regulates, among other things, that all prostitutes must register with the health office before they start working.
For this you need certain information and documents.
For example, you need proof of health consultation according to § 10 ProstSchG.
This takes place in the health office of the district administration.
You can make an appointment for a consultation here:
District Office Rems-Murr-Kreis
Gesundheitsamt (Health Department)
p-beratung@rems-murr-kreis.de
Health Department website
Further information on the Prostitution Protection Act in Baden-Württemberg can be found in different languages at www.bleibsafe.info.

questions.question: What are my basic rights in Germany?
Where can I get help if my rights are violated?
What does the German constitution say about equality?

context:
Basic Law and Human Rights
The Basic Law
In every country there are rules that all people must abide by.
The most important law for Germany is the Basic Law.
It is a collection of 146 articles.
Each article stands for a law, i.e. a rule.
These rules determine how people live together in Germany.
The basic rights protect the freedom of every individual.
They are laid down in Articles 1 to 19 of the Basic Law (catalogue of basic rights).
Here you can find the Basic Law in different languages.
Universal Declaration of Human Rights
Human rights are important rights that apply always and to all people around the world.
Human rights are rights that every human being has by virtue of being human.
They protect the dignity of every human being and are equally available to all without distinction of any kind, such as colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status.
There are 30 rights.
The most important are:
All people are of equal value.
Every person is allowed to have his or her own opinion.
The right to peace and security.
The rules for living together in Germany are derived from these basic rights.
The State Office for Political Education of North Rhine-Westphalia has published the brochure "Democracy for me" in which these rules are clearly presented.
These rules, as well as examples of what is and is not allowed in Germany, are presented here under each keyword.
